reviewText:
Differences between driving in ATS and real life:

Real Life....

-You can go to jail for hitting people

-You can get your license suspended

-Lawyers cost a fortune

-CDL's are expensive

-Vehicle insurances and taxes are expensive

ATS...

-Free CDL's

-You can be a dumbass driver and never go to jail

-Tickets don't cost anything (points against license or real money at least)

-You don't ruin your real wallet on fuel, insurance, taxes, etc

Overall 9/10 (at least until the east coast of 'Murica gets in the game)

reviewText:
Lazy.
Same game as ETS2. Same dumb driver faces, same lame truck sounds that make you want to put on euro skinny jeans and become a pillow biter, same dumb ai that crashes into you, rides up your a$$ when you're trying to turn around or need to pull that oversize gas tank into a gas station that is right of the road, so now you have to stop your parking attempt to clear ai cars that bunched up on both sides of the road, and be careful so you don't dink them cuz that's a $1000 fine. I set police to off right away after that. No more dumb fines.

Few years after ETS2 and you're telling me they couldn't make multiplayer? Two trucks only? Oh is it cuz of licensing or they spent their time on hookers n blow? They had trucks w/no license in ETS2, they just changed their names. I wouldn't care if I was driving Macs or Panchobilt if the dealer had bunch of trucks to choose from.

And every time I drive on the 5 up n down from LA I want to fly to whatever commie country devs are located n kick em in the balls since the real thing has like 12 lanes.. Not in game tho. Same lame 2 lanes with few stretches of short 3 lanes..ATS map is way scaled down because it's a ETS2 with a new map..

In the time of huge open world games this is what ATS brings to the table? roads that end with xxxxx marks you can't drive thru. So devs couldn't lay down roads every where in the game that you can just drive thru instead of being forced to this linear A to B path? Oh cuz the game is such a cpu hog? lol  With this old engine you could drive from mexico to Alaska and across the states.

reviewText:
SCS Software has done it again.

After the surprise massive hit that was Euro Truck Simulator 2, the developers decided to try their hand at expanding the trucking simulation game over to the good ol' US of A. I bought Euro Truck Simulator 2 on sale for $4.99 quite some time ago and have spent over 100 hours in it, as many have--it is one of those games I feel immensely guilty for buying on sale because of the quality of content and the massive enjoyment I get out of it. It is one of my top played games on Steam, and I currently own over 1,000 of them. It is also the only game I've ever bought DLC for (that wasn't part of the original package). In saying that, I own thousands of digital games (not just through Steam or even PC) and American Truck Simulator is the first digital game I've ever bought at full price (or at launch, for that matter).

American Truck Simulator is one of the few games that lives up to the simulator" title. It is a top notch simulation game where you must work your way up from an employee that drives trucks for other companies to a trucking business owner with dozens or more of drivers that report directly to you and make you income. It is a game that will scratch your simulation/business management/love of driving/relaxation itch all at once. This is not a stressful game. Quite the opposite
date: in fact. This is one of those games that you can zone out while playing and relax your mind after a stressful day. Everything about it has been meant to be relaxing
recommended: and it succeeds tremendously (even missing a loan payment earns you a politely worded letter from the bank telling you they'll extend the extra credit toward you free for a few days until you can pay them back).\n\nThe game works with various controllers
hoursPlayed: from a 360 gamepad (which I use) to wheels and such if you're interested. It also looks beautiful on higher end PCs

reviewText:
Played the game for 7 Hours so far, It's fu*king amazing SCS did a good job. There is defiantly some issues and it looks like the game was rushed but over all it's a good game.

Pros:  Overall good looking world
Has some new feature that are not in ETS2 (Weight Stations, E-Cards At Tolls, ETC)
Has actual Police that patrol and ticket you
Trucks feel and handle like they should.
Feature to choice difficulty of parking for extra XP.
Cons:  AI is still completely sh*t, they will cut you off, run into you, stop randomly just to ♥♥♥♥ you off.
Speed limit signs are incorrect, In quite a few areas the signs will say 65 and the real limit is 55.
Speed limit is unrealistic in many areas, I have found the speed limit to be 70 in some areas that you should be going over 30. Same with some areas are 30 but it should be 55.
Stop signs in random places for no reason:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=616055181
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=616097596
Police AI had potential but is now just a moving speed camera.
You tend to get ticketed by police for going 3 MPH over the limit, Kinda Aids.
I feel like I'm forgetting a few things...

Final Opinion This game has plenty of potential if they spend the time working on it.
I would give it a solid 8.7 out of 10
The game needs some work but is defiantly worth the $20, I would recommend that you get it on ♥♥♥ right now for $15.

Ok so after playing for a couple of hours i will give you my honest oppinion about this game.

reviewText:
Well, this is the new installment of SCS Software trucking simulators. I have been following this developer since I started PC gaming in 2007-2008. The 18 wheels of steel franchise will nostalgically always be with me.

Is this game worth the buy?
Yes, well it sort of depends on you.

Pros if you haven't played ETS 2:
-A more lively,creative,well done map.
-Has a ton of content.
-Is a great simulator
-The community and developers are great
-The map is large for only comprising of 2 states (the only ones out as I did this review)
-Does not get boring until hours into the game.
-Has a in-game streamable radio
-Is compatiable with every steering wheel,controller,and you can play using mouse,keyboard,and onion (not really.)

Pros if you have played ETS 2:
-No cities are the same

As you can see, this is a lot like ETS 2, but it has a lot of new content.

Cons:
-Is a lot like ETS 2.
-Has a smaller map at the moment
-Radio still hates Fall Out Boy (it skips them and some other artists songs for some reason)
-Only has 2 trucks

My score out of 100:
If you take in account ETS 2: 78/100
If you dont care about ETS 2 and is judging this game only: 90-91/100

Great game would run red lights again.

reviewText: This is the best trucking simulator to date. If you are looking for a way to just relax and take it easy, this is the game for you. The game can be hard, but only if you want it to be hard. You have almost complete control over the game which means you can make it easy if you are looking to just take it easy, or you can make it hard if youd like a bit of a challenge. With the easy to install mods as well as an already very nice game, you really can make this game whatever you would like it to be. If you are at all interested in this game, I highly suggest you go ahead and buy it. It is more than worth the price you pay with already free DLC that has either been released, or is in the works.\n\nIn conclusion, I definitely recommend this game if you think that this is something you would enjoy. It is well worth the price and can be edited to your liking. I hope this helps if you are on the fence on buying it, and I hope you have a wonderful time trucking!

reviewText:
I totally recommend this game, because the game is so well-polished and the gameplay is even more impressive than Euro Truck Simulator 2. I had never tried the Truck Simulator series, and I found that once I got it, I couldn't stop playing. Even though the map is currently small, the graphics have been improved from ETS2, and is currently at a rock-bottom price. I cannot wait for more DLC to come out, and eventually I hope that the game can expand to the whole of the USA.

This game is great for anyone, as it is super easy to learn, but is also challenging in it's own right to grow your company to a bigger level. Get it now while it is at a cheap price.

10/10

reviewText: I bought this as a fan of ETS2, however, I found myself dissapointed to the point of refunding the game. Why? The main thing that brought me to that conclusion was the scale in the game. A mile in game is equivalent to about 100 feet on the road,which makes a 100+ mile drive take about 10 minutes. Why does that drive of 100 miles (about 2 miles in real scale) take that long? Because the trucks are the most sluggish and poor handling things I've ever seen in a game like this. Having the petal matted to the floor and flat-foot shifting takes about 1 whole minute to get to 50mph. I can't recommend this game in this state.

reviewText:
First of all this game is based on ETS2 and I played ETS2 a lot. Now ATS was released and I didn't play ETS2 since ATS...
ATS is a slightly improved ETS2 taken to the US. And although it is based on ETS2 (which is very obvious from time to time e.g. the UI) it feels like a succesor, like progress and it feels like America should. The scale was changed, so that we have  more compressed map and time which does not break the feeling unless you played ETS2 right before playing ATS.
It features California and Nevada and someday we'll have the whole US in the game. The 3 featured trucks were made with the standards of ETS2 trucks. You'll feel how different they are (from each other and from the ETS2 trucks).

After playing over a 100 hours I can recommend this to people that are interested in driving trucks through America the beautiful...

reviewText:
American Truck Simulator is a strong evolution of SCS's trucking sim formula. The core loop of pickup, drive, and deliver (with a dash of business management) is still there from ETS2. Cruising from the bustling cities in California, trough the barren night desert, and into a small town in Nevada is as satisfying as ever.

The map's scale may be smaller than ETS2, but ATS's world is much more dense and interesting. The use of vanilla ETS2's assets was very similar in every city. That is no longer the case with ATS. From the base level, there are straight up more things to see as you cruise from destination to destination. When assets ARE reused, they are done so in such a creative manner that you probably won't notice on first glance.

Most notable of the new assets are the new locations where jobs are taken and delivered. Not only are they much more varied than ETS2, but there's an increased level of challenge when parking. Larger trucks and longer trailers combined with tight quarters and required blind-side backing make some of the drop-offs downright difficult. In fact, the difficulty as a whole has increased with ATS. The mobile police cars make avoiding speeding fines more complex than just cheesing speed cameras. Also, the rebalanced economy seems to have made it a little less easy to earn loads of money.

However, there are still flaws. Unprotected, at-grade left turns onto freeways are a nightmare. The freeway traffic will never let up, so any AI in front of you will never be able to pull out. Even if you're lucky enough to be first in line at the turn, you'll end up slowly nudging your way into traffic to try and block them long enough to make it through. Then there are the small pockets of the road system where the speed limit rapidly changes from 70 to 30 to 55. God help you if a cop spots you going 31 in the midst of braking. Lastly, some truck customization parts are not present, such as air horns and extra lights.

(UPDATE 2016/05/02 - SCS has since added protected left turns to some areas and made the speed limit changes more gradual. There are still a few rough spots, but way less than on release.)

Overall, I am really pleased with ATS at the $20 price point, which is the same as the Scandinavian DLC for ETS2 when it came out. There may only be two trucks and two states, but SCS has been good about supporting ETS2 and they are showing no signs of changing. They've already confirmed at LEAST two more trucks, and the state of Arizona as free DLC. It will be interesting to see their plan for paid DLC to cover the rest of the country.

reviewText:
I have held of saying something but it IS necessary! You will see only two hours here but I have 126hrs on ETS2! The games are the same in mechanics! Should I buy ATS? Of course you should, its a must have! BUT, at this stage its a HUGE dissapointment. If the devs had all the ground work in game production already done for them, why have we waited so long for a game so thin in content. The trucks are beefy and American which is awesome and the landscape is real, but really, you want me to drive in such a short hop all the way to Redding??? NO NO NO, people - ATS makes Cally look the size of Luxemborg!!! All said and done, I love the titles and I love the concept and ethos start of ATS but if you are going to make ATS work as well as ETS2 you better get some real content fast and you better get some mileage scaling sorted out. Lastly and Im not just harping at you guys but devs are supposed to be wizz kids and for all the simplicity behind the actual coding of a project like this, it is REALLY DISSAPOINTING that the two games dont talk to each other! It isnt rocket science to do that! To sum up, I undertsand that thousands of hours and more go into the graphics of designing maps, but hey, you have a following here so lets get busy, we dont mind paying for good dlc's for more content but we cannot have ATS representing USA as smaller than Europe????

Please take this as a positive gripe, we love the series, we want more?

Again, should you buy it, how could you live without it? But if you have clocked the miles on ETS2 - AT THIS STAGE, you WILL be left a little dissapointed with ATS!

reviewText:
Initially I was apprehensive about buying the game due to the small size of it compared to ETS and ETS2, and over scaling making the roads far too short. However, I bought it after playing around with the demo and realising that it is all relative. Don't get me wrong, the map is small, and the longest drive I've done so far lasted no more than 40 minutes (I've spent a couple hours on a single job in ETS2). I have no doubt this will change over time, but I feel SCS has cheated the game by only releasing two initial states.

Pros:
- Challenging driving with longer trailers
- Selectable trailer drop off locations
- Detailed scenery and roads

Cons:
- The map is far too small in its current
- Lack of trucks
- Idiotic AI and overly harsh traffic penalty enforcement

This game is good for people who want a step up from the driving in ETS and ETS2, but I wouldn't strongly suggest people who own those games to get this as it feels more like a DLC or gimick having played the previous two games.

For those who've never played a truck sim, this offers a unique and in-depth entry into the game type.

TL:DR
Good game that challenges your driving skills, but map is too small.

reviewText:
Pretty much ETS2 with American trucks and a smaller, but highly detailed map. You play as a truck driver who has no cash, no truck, nothing. You do quick jobs by driving for other companies till you can afford your own truck. Once you own a truck, you are free to explore and discover cities where you can find pickup and drop off points for trailers, truck dealers, recruitment agencies, and more.

Once you've earned a considerable amount of cash, you can upgrade our garage and buy additional trucks and hire drivers for added income. You can buy more garages in different cities to further expand your business.

Pros:
- Very vibrant and beautiful graphics
- Easy to use interface (Carried over from ETS2)
- Highly detailed map with excellent attention to detail
- Highly detailed trucks with interior
- Realistic Driving physics
- Realistic Driving laws
- Simple to use Sat Nav
- Controller, wheel, joystick support
- Mods support
- Photomode and World of Trucks
- Multiplayer mod (Truckers MP)

Cons:
- Very poor optimization; you may need a good GPU to run smoothly
- Small map (Free & Paid Expansions soon to come)
- Limited truck selection (More to come within the next few months)
- Daft AI (Similar to ETS2)
- Police cars spawn too often and are not forgiving when speeding
- Spawn rate of certain AI cars are unrealistic
- Lack of slip roads on freeway intersections
- Horn sounds like a computer making error noises

reviewText:
Right at this moment, I can't recommend this game. It is very bare bones, with only Califonia and Nevada currently available. I find myself driving on the same roads over and over again, which gets very, boring very fast.

There are currently only 3 trucks in the game, 1 Peterbilt and 2 Kenworth, and therefore there are only 3 types of trucks the NPC's drive, which again is pretty boring to look at. There are also very few models of cars currently in the game.

The HUD and GUI are identical to Euro Truck Simulator 2, with only a couple of new icons added, which seems a bit lazy.

After ~8 hours of playtime, I've discovered ~50% of the map, and I could probably have discovered 70% if I had just driven around instead of doing jobs. Additionally I've done 60% of the Steam achievements already.

I can only recommend this if you are a Peterbilt or Kenworth enthusiast, but for everyone else, there really isn't that much to see or do in the game right now.

So as you can see the pro's way out do the cons. I would recomeded this game as I think it will get better with time.

reviewText:
I wanted to review this game and give it a good one because I like ETS2 and I wanted to support the devs. But, I thought it would not be right to do as (too) many people do and post a review (good or bad) without even taking time to try the game. So I played close to 5h and made at least 5 deliveries with and without owned truck before writing this.

/!\ I will compare alot with ETS2 so if you are not familiar with this game, probably this review wont be the best so feel free to ask anything in comments below /!\n
Let's start with short review for those who don't want to read a novel and then I'll give more in depth of my thoughts for those who want to know more (keep in mind those facts" are my own appreciation of the game and could differ for others):

PROS
- Graphics are as good as ETS2 (Scandinavia)
- Map
- Muuuuurica!
- Maneuverability different from ETS2 ---> parking trailer is so much more fun and challenging
- Weight stations
- Cops
- Higher amount of car models
- Stop signs (not only red lights anymore)
- Can turn right on red light as long as you do a stop before (as in real life eh eh)

CONS
- Graphics are as good as ETS2 (Scandinavia)
- Map
- Cops
- Lower amount of truck models
- No World of trucks deliveries.. not yet... it's probably coming ;)
- no multiplayer --> i hope they'll consider it as the map will grow..

Graphics are as good as ETS2 (Scandinavia) : It is good and bad at same time. Good because this mean you dont need an asskicking new gen high end PC to run this game

reviewText: SCS Software has done it again. Most people who follow SCS (I myself since 18 WoS: Haulin') don't need to look at reviews to decide to purchase their games, but if you're new to the driving sim genre, this is what you're looking for. The landscapes are incredibly detailed, a good balance of easy cruising routes and chalenging back roads. On top of all that, SCS listens to their customers; A widely desired feature can be expected to be put in a patch in the coming months. This game has many many years ahead of it, just like Euro Truck Simulator 2. The modding community is also very positive. Stable, well done, useful mods can be expected.

reviewText:
I was a bit hesitant to buy this game after reading the reviews about the map scaling being wonky compared to ETS2. I actually waited a week or so after release, then decided to go ahead and buy it. I have zero regrets. This game is absolutely enjoyable, as it is an entirely different experience driving in ATS than it is ETS2. I still play ETS2, and will always have a fond love for that game.

The graphics are gorgeous, the trucks are even more so, and if you're new to ETS/ETS2/ATS, then I highly recommend you buy this (even ETS2, while you're at it). I have few gripes about the game, including the map scaling which really doesn't bother me all that much; the on-ramps on freeways are extremely short and not at all realistic, but again it doesn't detract from the game as a whole. Perhaps my biggest gripe would be the lack of states out of the gate. I understand there is a lot behind this game already, however, Arizona is the last free DLC that will be added to the game, which is still a few months away from release. It would have been nice if SCS would have done the entire Western United States as free DLC, maybe Arizona, Utah, Colorado, New Mexico, Wyoming, Idaho, Washington, and Oregon. Then had gone from there, just so there is quite a lot of distance to cover while they work on cranking out the paid DLC.

Regardless, I love this game. While I have low hours played on it, don't let that deter you any. I play a variety of other games and love to give them equal attention. If you're able to, I suggest getting a steering wheel with pedals to add to that realistic touch. I play on a gaming laptop, so I have to use the keyboard which if you don't have the option of getting a steering wheel, still get this. Keyboard is still fun and the only thing you may have trouble with is backing the trailer up into position.

I know this review is a bit scatter brained, and I apologize if it is a hard read. I hope with the paid DLC that they do it in regions, such as Mid-West, Eastern, etc., and not state-by-state. The game itself is $20, so I am hoping that the paid DLC stays under that price range. Get this game. You'll enjoy it, and have a blast.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: The counterpart to Euro Truck Simulator 2, American Truck Simulator takes SCS Software's classic European driving experience and brings it to the United States. American Truck Simulator is built off of the same game engine as Euro Truck Simulator 2, and it shares the same principle of its predecessor, where you start as a driver for hire before starting your own trucking company. Because of this shared engine, the game also supports the same control methods as its counterpart, such as racing wheels, gamepad controllers, and even the keyboard; the complexity of the controls can can be adjusted for an easier or more challenging driving experience. Like Euro Truck Simulator 2, American Truck Simulator is also under constant development. Although the base game was only released with two trucks and the states of California and Nevada, a new truck has since been added to the game for free, and the state of Arizona and another new truck will also be released as free DLC soon. However, what really sets American Truck Simulator apart from its European counterpart, and makes up for the initial lack of map and truck-related content, is the variety of unique elements added to the game. Larger and more detailed cities, randomly appearing police cars giving speeding tickets, random weigh station inspections, and the ability to make right turns at red lights make for a more interesting and enjoyable trucking experience. And even though the game is relatively new, there is a large and growing modding community; even though I personally don't use mods, there are many available which add features such as new truck models and even multiplayer support. Even though I think that the game is already pretty good as it is, if you are willing to be patient and wait for the aditional content, you will not be disappointed.

reviewText:
For $20 bucks this game far exceeds any expectations. ATS provides a uniqe view into the world of a truck driver from just getting your CDL and driving loaner or company trucks to buying your first truck and becoming an Owner/ Operator. This game doesnt exactly scream excitement and if your coming from a FPS you may be initialy disapointed, but the steady hum of the diesel engine and the whine of the tires on the highway will suck you in, and if that doesnt do it for ya, take a cruise up high way 1 and take a look at the STUNNING scenery they've put into this game. The only addition I would like to see to this game would be to add buyable trailers so you can haul loads with your own truck and trailer and make more mola!!  18 WOS had this and Id really like to see it in this evolution.

All that said if your into driving sims, or want to try it out and see if its in your interest I absolutly recommend this game as it is a fine example of quality content and involved developers.

I strongly recomend using a decent quality racing wheel or at a minimum a game pad (I currently use an xbox one controller) to get the most out of this game.

reviewText:
I think what motivated me the most to write a review was the lame negative reviews.

First off, I feel I must set the proper context for this review. This game is early in it's evolutionary journey. I see much potential in this. There are features missing or not setup it seems, but nothing big.

- The game seems lacking, in tucks and map, however they're working on it. The licenses are all that is left for the trucks and the maps are part of the ongoing evolution of the game, ETS2 style.
- The game is essentially an ETS2 total conversion.  Is that bad? No. Why fix what isn't broken?
- Traffic appears to have some improvement. It still has the blind driver that stupidly runs into you once in a while.

The game has a western US feel to it, driving through California or Nevada. It feels more immersive than ETS2, I find. I'm not far into it, but I enjoy a relaxing drive while listening to the radio.

Suggestions?

My brother was suggesting tandem trucks, box trucks, maybe even expand into tow trucks and big rig tow trucks. I won't mention map expansion as I understand that is the long term plan.

Though I feel like I'm asking way too much for this next idea, but I would love to be able to get out of my truck, walk around, inspect & secure the load, Bring the feet down to disconnect the trailer, hook up any applicable cables/hoses... etc.

I remember the game, Rig'n Roll. It was more story oriented, but I enjoyed it. I liked the story feel to that game. It added a little personality.

A suggestion for SCS, which could generate some extra income:
Implement real advertisements on billboards around town and highways. Lots of potential for some passive income. It could help keep DLC costs down. Or free.

I think ATS has a very bright future.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is just amazing! I play this game just to relax and take my mind off of stuff.

If you enjoy simulators then this game is a great game to add to your list. It is pretty realistic and very detailed graphics wise. It has mod support (one of which is a multiplayer mod that I'll decribe as well). Regarding mods: Say you don't like the slim choices of trucks (which keep in mind they are adding more trucks and even more states soon), but you can just download a different truck design or even a car if you don't want to drive a truck.

In regards to the Mp mod: I will say that it doesnt have ai which is good and bad because no ai driving around means less lag with other players and not having to deal with stupid ai (which you still have to deal with some stupid player not understanding the physics or how its a simulator or whatever the reason is). What's bad about not having ai is that in this game the only way of getting fined for speeding is by cops (there are very little speed cameras), so people just decide to break all the laws because they can't get punished (or they don't care). And it's not like admin aren't there moderating it because they are.

All in all I would say to get this game but if simulators aren't your thing then just go play your shooters or whatever you find joy out of because this game needs more serious people especially in Mp. 9/10

reviewText: It's a clear morning in California. I'm driving my truck down a lonely road, through the empty desert. In the rear view mirror, I see a car approaching. I keep driving, expecting them to pass me, but they don't. I check back in my mirror, and- it's a police car. Okay, this is no situation to panic. I kept driving, slowly and steadily. But I felt myself growing tired. The road stretched on, seemingly endlessly. I finally could take no more and dozed off for anly a few seconds. When I woke up, I was going slightly above the speed limit, and I slammed my brakes. But it was too late. The police car had already called reinforcements. A line of six or seven cop cars was following me down the highway, sirens blaring. I suddenly get a storm of notifications from my GPS- my bank account is being drained, ticket by ticket. Then the shooting started, and they drove the truck off the road. That was the last thing I remembered, until I woke up. The starving, broke, pitiful CEO of a failed trucking company.\n\n10/10, quite realistic.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful 4 people found this review funny

reviewText:
[MEH] For now!

Pros-
- Beautiful graphics and scenery.  Albeit it's not a large world as the world we live in but for the sake of time and video gaming, they slimmed it down.  Thank you for that!
- Can't progress quite quickly.  This I love.  I hate games that give you a ton of xp and money and the results are a finished engame in a matter of hours.  It's taken me over 10 hours to get to level 6.  Max level is 20.
- InGame radio.

Cons-
- Speed limit changes in a fraction of a second. If you're driving on a road that's 55, without warning it willchange to 30.  As soon as you cross over that barrier, you get a fine up to $1,000.
- Lack of trucks early on.  The game feels empty.
- Get's kinda boring driving from point A to B.  What do you expect, it's a truck simulator.
- Price is actually heavy.  I thought it wasn't at first but when I saw the game was empty and DLC was gonna cost money; yea, price is too expensive.  Feels like a $9.99 product with DLC content for money.
- Can't use your picture for profile even though the game is not online.

It's a cool game if you want to experience being a trucker.  If you ask me, it's grand theft auto without the silly stuff and characters.  Go drive a truck in Grand Theft Auto V.

Not worth $20 just yet.

EDIT: This game is full of bugs and lacks the name of SIMULATION".  It's too time consuming with no real goals but to drive from point A to B making virtual currency.  Don't waste your time on this game."

reviewText:
[MEH] For now!

Pros-
- Beautiful graphics and scenery.  Albeit it's not a large world as the world we live in but for the sake of time and video gaming, they slimmed it down.  Thank you for that!
- Can't progress quite quickly.  This I love.  I hate games that give you a ton of xp and money and the results are a finished engame in a matter of hours.  It's taken me over 10 hours to get to level 6.  Max level is 20.
- InGame radio.

Cons-
- Speed limit changes in a fraction of a second. If you're driving on a road that's 55, without warning it willchange to 30.  As soon as you cross over that barrier, you get a fine up to $1,000.
- Lack of trucks early on.  The game feels empty.
- Get's kinda boring driving from point A to B.  What do you expect, it's a truck simulator.
- Price is actually heavy.  I thought it wasn't at first but when I saw the game was empty and DLC was gonna cost money; yea, price is too expensive.  Feels like a $9.99 product with DLC content for money.
- Can't use your picture for profile even though the game is not online.

It's a cool game if you want to experience being a trucker.  If you ask me, it's grand theft auto without the silly stuff and characters.  Go drive a truck in Grand Theft Auto V.

Not worth $20 just yet.

EDIT: This game is full of bugs and lacks the name of SIMULATION".  It's too time consuming with no real goals but to drive from point A to B making virtual currency.  Don't waste your time on this game."

reviewText: Great truck simulation game, SCS did us proud! It gives you a challenge but of course it is still fun at the same time. Very realistic, lots of details and even more than ETS2 I would say. The choice of trucks to start off isn't too bad, but of course it could be better but that will all be done when SCS get the required licenses to include more brands. The two starting states - California and Nevada were a great choice to start off with, as I'm quite familiar with the state of California and know my way around a fair bit. Amazing game SCS, well worth the money!

reviewText:
Well ATS I only play online so can n ot comment on the single player.
I really like this game and its a good replacement for ETS2, I have had some fun driving the big rigs with the amazingly long tarialers.
I like the feel of the GFX engine for the most its smooth and runs nicely but in heavily populated areas the frames can drop to jerky sub 25fps and sometimes it may drop just below 50fps its really random im using a GTX970.

I haven't played now for a week and a half as I have discovered everything have 30+ trucks and a very steady income.

The good.

beautiful landscapes
Good GFX engine 99% of the time
Tumble weed :P
Much more challenging  trailer parking than ETS2
Long Long Roads.
CB radio 10-4

The Bad
Maps are to small and easily completed
Random Frame drops :(
No Air Horn (really!!!!!)
Not enough trucks
less customization than ETS2
Long Long roads
Some glitches when trucks drive over the humpy roads
Weigh Bridges pointless
Traffic lights red turn right get fined sometimes !

Thats about it I do like the game just need much more content.

reviewText: Driving the roads, blasting the radio, hauling A$$! Well thats the point of this game, Its a driving sim at its finest. I would recommend this to anyone looking for a semi (get it? lol) relaxing driving game. I said semi though because if you do not follow the traffic laws (which can be turned off) and avoid the other drivers (that are seemingly soccer moms) the game can be a real challenge. The scenery going down the road is nice as well. Would love to see a few more in depth things added such as current market trends (Right now it seems you haul the same thing over and over if you just want to make the big bucks). Also, other than being able to customize your truck its actually better to just drive for a company. Much easier to make the cash. Adding in Multiplayer (which is currently only available in MOD form) would have made this game even better. So what are you waiting for? Get out on that Road now!\n\n7 out of 10 Overall a solid game but could be fleshed out a bit more as well as some multiplayer support, Also future maps will be DLC so the game has potential to become a moneygrab.

reviewText:
I had awaited ATS after getting into ETS.. when ATS came out I loved it, although briefly.
Sadly.. I got distracted with some other games.. and now I just have not gotten back into it.
It however is in full install in my library.. and for those who know me.. that means it will receive play time again.
If you like truck sims, this is a really well done game.  The content is being updated, the game play still patched. I still follow it faithfully.
I recently decided that since so many more maps are in the works I am just going to hold off for one or two before I jump back in. That may or may not stay true.. depends on the time it takes. But this is one that will have me driving again.
Sure, its not perfect. Nothing ever is. But for an OTR simulation.. highly advise it as a buy.

reviewText:
The Freerider"
~ By Robertson Crusoe

"Whenever I take a job
date: may it be heavy load or a simple drive
recommended: I feel strange. I would always turn my head and see my bed behind the drivers seat and I know I am already home. Because my home is where I am. I would turn the radio on and listen to classic rock. Than I would turn on the engine and drive my truck through valleys and fields and towns and unknown places. Cars will pass me. Some will vanish in the rearview as the cities fade out when I leave them. And I drive and I am free.\n\nBut than I wake up. I see the clock and know the alarm clock will go off soon. And I realize that I am caged and that I am just sitting in front of a screen showing me a life that I don't have but that I always desired. And my 9 to 5 job calls me and I work papers I don't understand and I don't connect. And I am a servant to my income. To pay for my home. But when I am back home
hoursPlayed: I will turn the engine on again and ride freely through a place that only exists in my dream.\n\nI am the freerider. And I am already home. Home.""

reviewText:
This is one of those games that similar to ETS2 will having me doing a few jobs a day for months on end.

It does not revolutionize the sim genre as its very similar to ETS2. However its improves on most all of it. Scenery is more detailed in cities. Outside of cities its about as detailed as it can be for mostly desert areas. It does feel quite a bit smaller than ETS2 mainly because its 2 states at the moment. Which is disappointing but from what I hear Nevada is in the works and will be free so cannot complain to much about that.

The modding scene is in the works as well so I have no doubt in a few months we will have some amazing mods to go along with it. There are already some great mods for the game. I am excited for the maps mods.

What impressed me the most was the sounds. I love ETS2 but when you get in one of these Peterbuilt or Kenworth trucks and get your truck moving it gives you chills.

I have got 2 other drivers working for me and am well into making my trucking empire. For me this was a no brainer. I loved ETS2 however I prefer the North American setting so I grabbed this.

I know this review is kind of all over the place. Moral of the story. If you have and enjoy ETS2 and are looking for something different this is not the game for you there is not enough to recommend switching. However if you prefer the setting by all means grab this game you will not be disappointed.

If you have never owned one of the trucking sim games but are interested. Choose which setting you prefer most and pick it up.
voteText: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: What made me buy this game in the first place is that I was playing GTA 5 and really enjoyed playing taxi, but really wanted a game that was more realistic in terms of actually driving around. Having never played a simulator ever before (as I usually stick with games that are not so realistic) I decided to try this one, because I'm always up for new things. First thing I am going to say is that if you're a graphic ♥♥♥♥♥ who only wants the best graphics, this is not the game for you. Also the traffic AI and citations are not the best either. However, if you can look past those flaws, the game is really great. Having experienced a little bit of the real thing, I can say it is fairly accurate to what being a truck driver is actually like. It's especially impressive considering that this is an indie game. My only real big complaint is the size. I would have actually liked all of America to be in it, instead of just Nevada and California. Also changing seasons and in game events based on in game dates would be a great way to expand the game. As it is, it's still worth the time and money and I think this was a great introductory into the simulation genre for me and for anyone else looking to get into simulation games.

reviewText: Clearly the negitive review people did not read anything about this game before purchasing it. Those complaining about lack of map: They stated that the states will be released as future DLC. Seeing as how California alone is twice the size of the U.K I can see how it would take a bit of time to develop. As for the lack of trucks they ran into licensing issues with the truck companies BUT they did say after a few weeks they should have the go ahead to put more trucks into the game, which will be free updates. The only issue I really have with the game is the ridiculous amount of police around so just starting out you loose money quick from speeding tickets. Also to those complaining about the 55 mph limit on some highways: In California the law is trucks with trailers statewide cannot go over 55 mph. When you get into Nevada and eventually elsewhere the speed limit goes up to a decent speed. Overall I rate this high as the future of this game will be rather well once they get more states and trucks up.

reviewText:
Updated 2/26/016
If you are a hardcore fan of ETS2, then I highly recommend getting this game. It's the same engine, concept, layout, and core mechanics so you'll feel right at home. Despite the game not being listed as Early Access, you might as well consider it as being so. The amount of content is a little on the light side as of now, but more content (both free and paid) is definitely on the way. The content that is in the game is much higher quality than that in ETS2. The world is very detailed and feels rather lived in.

Compared to ETS2, the difficulty and amount of grinding has been bumped up a tad. Speeding fines have since been toned down and the Police are a bit less insane in the recent update thanks to SCS. I definitely find this game requires a lot more of my attention while playing. I personally play with a Logitech G27 and a TrackIR; I wouldn't recommend trying to play with a keyboard and mouse, but if you're determined, feel free to give it a go.

The game now has three trucks, with a fourth potentially coming soon, and two states with a third in development. Modders have already rolled out a decent amount of content already, including a multiplayer mod. I find the combination of official and unofficial content to definitely be worth the $20, but that's just me.

reviewText: Call of Duty rodem z SCS: masa nazistów z MG42, MP40 i innymi cudami, naprzeciw Ty, masz wiele chęci i... nóż. Pistolet, karabin i granaty otrzymasz w DLC. Kiedyś. A do tego czasu musisz sobie z radzić. Poważnie? Dwa ciągniki? OK, rozumiem, licencje, i inne takie. Ale bez przesady, Peterbilt oferuje 3 modele ciągników, Kenworth - 4. A my co dostaliśmy? Jeden Peterbilt i Kenworth i kolejne modele Kena i Peterbilta w DLC. Kiedyś. To jakaś kpina. A gdzie Mack, Volvo, Freightliner, Western Star, etc, etc? To jakiś żart? Sprawdziłem, dziś jest 3 lutego, a nie 1 kwietnia. I to nie jest śmieszne. Oczywiście, gra posiada sporo zalet, klimat np jest świetny. Tyle że w tej chwili to nie ma żadnego znaczenia. CoD bez broni też pewnie miałby swoje zalety, tylko co z tego? Ktoś z Was chciałby grać w CoD-a z nożem? Nie sądzę, choćby nie wiem ile zalet by miał. Smutna prawda jest taka, że SCS kroi 20 euro za niedokończoną grę. Jak dla mnie to najzwyklejsze złodziejstwo i rozbój w biały dzień. Wstyd! Jeśli chcesz kupić ATS to jak najbardziej zrób to, ale nie teraz. Nie bądź głupi jak ja, kup go kiedy SCS go łaskawie skończy robić. Kiedyś. 1/10\n\nCall of Duty made by SCS: lot of nazis with MG42 and MP40 against you, and you have a ... knife. Pistol, rifle and grenades you will get in DLC. Someday. Until then you must to deal with it. Really? Two trucks? OK, I understand, licenses, etc. But Peterbilt offers 3 models of tractors, Kenworth - 4. And we what got? One Peterbilt and Kenworth and other one models of Ken & Pete in the DLC. Someday. And where's Mack, Volvo, Freightliner, Western Star, etc, etc? It's some kind of joke? Today is February 3rd, not April 1st, and no, it's not funny. Of course, the game also has lot of advantages, but at this moment it doesn't matter. CoD without weapons also probably would have advantages, but so what? It's would unplayable, like ATS in this moment. The sad truth is that the SCS takes 20EUR for unfinished game, and it's daylight robbery! Shame! If you want to buy ATS - do it, but not now. Don't be a fool like me, buy ATS when they will be finished. Someday. 1/10

reviewText:
As an avid player of Euro Truck Simulator, I decided to give American Truck Simulator a go. It's an enjoyable game in a new environment with different vehicles, however that's where the differences end... all in all, it's just Euro Truck. But that's not a bad thing, the game gives you a new environment to drive though with incredible detailing, I did however find a few negatives that hindered the experience,

- Police Cars, these have replaced speed cameras and are mobile, often catching you out.
- Speed Changes, linking to the point above, not enough signs and speeds change before you have time to notice, resulting in a hefty fine.
- AI Traffic, when joining the freeway, even if the outside lane is clear the AI will not let you go, meaning you either force your way out or you stop and wait for age.

These are my only negatives, if you're looking for a trucking simulator then seriously consider this or ETS, depending on what you're interested in more.

reviewText:
After only spending a few hours in ATS, I feel like I've found a game I can just play forever and ever and never get tired of.  I was hesitant about buying it, as I know nothing of trucking, nor did I get into ETS 2 or other similar games, making this my introduction to trucking games.  I took the risk and bought it thanksto a friend, and I can't stop playing.  It is extremely fun and relaxing to just drive and/or listen to the in-game radio.  The game is beautiful!  SCS did an amazing job  with graphic details.

I do, however, have a few issues with the game.  These are mostly minor things that don't  take away from the gameplay overall.  I'm thoroughly loving this game.

1)  Speeding tickets are 1k each, even if you'ree only going 5 miles over.  That's pretty extreme and not realistic.

2) Cops are EVERYWHERE.  I love seeing the cops around, but it gets to be a little too much when every fourth or fifth car you see is a police car.

3) I've encountered certain spots in gas stations that the truck simply cannot go over.  I found this out initially when delivering fuel.  My cab could go over the spot, but my trailer wheels would get stuck and force me to skip parking.

4) Traffic speeds!  Cars will go much faster than you all the time, even if you're going 55mph, they will fly by you.  If we have a set speed limit, the AI needs one, too.

reviewText:
I'll try to keep this short and somewhat readable :

If you were an Euro Truck Simulator 2 fan and are intimidated by the seemingly small size of the current content - don't be.
SCS has shown more than high aptitude to deliver high quality content with time. It may be less content than you are used to, but it's fresh, and my god is it polished.

It's beautiful, the controls are tight and intuitive, as well as incredibly configurable - and it seemingly runs smoother the prettier it looks - don't know what kind of nail polish SCS works with, but it works perfectly on my 2012 war victim.

As a final note : remember the devs took several steps to have the world size of Euro Truck Simulator 2 as it is. There was its prequel, and the prequel to that (Scania Truck Simulator). And on top of that, the game got massive expansions, and multiple patches that added cities in Italy, Austria and Hungary.
You honestly think SCS didn't or won't deliver? Well if you do, I can't do much to convince you otherwise. But they can. For 20 (local currency) it's worth it.

tl;dr : BELIEVE in the developer. Particularly this one.

reviewText:
I took a whole new aproach to playing ATS than I did in ETS2.

In ETS 2 I went for world domination so to speak.  I have all the drivers with upgraded trucks working for me with over 100 of them at level 10.  All the garages maxed out.  All acheivements done and all the money in the world with nothing really to spend it on.  The game became a bit boring because I had nothing to achieve.  I still had fun delivering loads but not like before.

In ATS I decided to not hire any drivers and instead work hard to save enough to buy my truck and etc.  Its amazing how much harder the game is when you have to worry about not getting tickets or in accidents.  I am enjoying the new approach to the game.

Now the game is in good playable condition but not in perfect shape yet and content is on the low side but I have no dought SCS is going to continue improving the game, adding content wheither free or dlc and etc.  They know they have a winner with lots of room to grow as long as they play their cards right with what they plan to charge for as dlc and what will be free.

reviewText:
It's a subtle spell that American Truck Simulator casts, yet one whose alchemy can be surprisingly complex. The roads are filled with more traffic than prior games, and it's dictated by convincing AI; fellow road-users are beholden to the same everyday rule-set as you, stopping at traffic lights and observing a speed limit that fluctuates as you cross state-lines and keeping an eye out for patrolling police cars that enforce the laws of the road. Negotiating busy highways offers its own challenge, the mirror-signal-manoeuvre that precedes a lane-change becoming a part of your vocabulary as trusty as Street Fighter's quarter-circle fireballs.

Ticking beneath all this like a diesel thrum are the systems that piece each journey together; the acquisition of XP that sees you level up and opens up more trucks and more parts, the growing income that allows you to buy more garages, to hire more drivers and to take on more jobs. There's a satisfying sense of progression that sits neatly alongside your excursions, which themselves can escalate as you move on: longer journeys see you battling fatigue and looking for rest-stops lest you fall asleep at the wheel.

If that all sounds familiar, well it is. Beyond the shift in location and a handful of very minor tweaks - those patrolling police cars, the ability to haul longer cargo and a slightly fancier GPS unit - this is quite simply Euro Truck Simulator 2 with a new lick of chrome and transposed to America, with the front-end and all the slow crawl of empire building it enables near-identical. In many ways, it's a more limited game, too.

More is on its way, and given how Euro Truck Simulator 2 quickly expanded thanks to SCS Software and the modding community's efforts, it's safe to assume American Truck Simulator will slowly fill out. Right now, though, it's an openly modest game - with a £14.99 price tag to reflect that - rather than a full-blown sequel. What you're currently buying into is the pull of those American roads, and the slightly mysterious promise of where they'll head next; Arizona is next on the menu, and after that there's the hope that SCS Software could head all the way to the midwest and beyond.

reviewText:
I get the criticism this game receives, e.g. that it looks like a mod / DLC for ETS2 and that it's way too expensive. However, I find this game still very fun and challenging AND worth the money.

The scenery is completely different and the challenge is there. You get to choose while delivering if you want to take the easy way out: automatic parking, the easy challenge: parking in an easy spot or to pick the advanced spot. You get more XP for taking a tougher challenge.  I think that this game is no where near done. It lacks diversity  after a while and new things to unlock, but you can't flat out compare Euro truck simulator 2 with American truck simulator. ATS will be greater or equal to ETS2 in the future as SCS has shown in the past with ETS2.

7/7

reviewText:
It's a subtle spell that American Truck Simulator casts, yet one whose alchemy can be surprisingly complex. The roads are filled with more traffic than prior games, and it's dictated by convincing AI; fellow road-users are beholden to the same everyday rule-set as you, stopping at traffic lights and observing a speed limit that fluctuates as you cross state-lines and keeping an eye out for patrolling police cars that enforce the laws of the road. Negotiating busy highways offers its own challenge, the mirror-signal-manoeuvre that precedes a lane-change becoming a part of your vocabulary as trusty as Street Fighter's quarter-circle fireballs.

Ticking beneath all this like a diesel thrum are the systems that piece each journey together; the acquisition of XP that sees you level up and opens up more trucks and more parts, the growing income that allows you to buy more garages, to hire more drivers and to take on more jobs. There's a satisfying sense of progression that sits neatly alongside your excursions, which themselves can escalate as you move on: longer journeys see you battling fatigue and looking for rest-stops lest you fall asleep at the wheel.

If that all sounds familiar, well it is. Beyond the shift in location and a handful of very minor tweaks - those patrolling police cars, the ability to haul longer cargo and a slightly fancier GPS unit - this is quite simply Euro Truck Simulator 2 with a new lick of chrome and transposed to America, with the front-end and all the slow crawl of empire building it enables near-identical. In many ways, it's a more limited game, too.

More is on its way, and given how Euro Truck Simulator 2 quickly expanded thanks to SCS Software and the modding community's efforts, it's safe to assume American Truck Simulator will slowly fill out. Right now, though, it's an openly modest game - with a £14.99 price tag to reflect that - rather than a full-blown sequel. What you're currently buying into is the pull of those American roads, and the slightly mysterious promise of where they'll head next; Arizona is next on the menu, and after that there's the hope that SCS Software could head all the way to the midwest and beyond.

reviewText: Do I recommend this game? YES! At its Current State it only has 2 states for you to drive on, and 2 trucks.... however the communtiy on this game is amazing , mods for extra trucks, more AI vehicles, paintjobs etc. were all being released hours after the release of the game! Without downloading Multiplayer or extra mods would I still recommend this game? Yes, because even without all that stuff its alot of fun to just sit down from a long day and relax and drive a truck around America, so if you are thinking of buying this game go for it 10/10!

reviewText: Here's an old reference. 18 Wheels of Steel. I'm not talking about the Extreme Trucker versions, I'm talking about the originals. Hard Truck, Haulin, Convoy etc. Now this. This game seems to me like an extreme overhaul of the 18WoS games. There's HD graphics, supreme truck customization (except for custom liveries), a wide range of companies and loads, and, a feature used in 18WoS Haulin, hired drivers. Not only that, the immersion factor within the terrain and the trucks is through the roof. It's not just haulin loads any more. It now lets you enjoy the view. One recommendation, better rendered drivers.

reviewText:
After only spending a few hours in ATS, I feel like I've found a game I can just play forever and ever and never get tired of.  I was hesitant about buying it, as I know nothing of trucking, nor did I get into ETS 2 or other similar games, making this my introduction to trucking games.  I took the risk and bought it thanksto a friend, and I can't stop playing.  It is extremely fun and relaxing to just drive and/or listen to the in-game radio.  The game is beautiful!  SCS did an amazing job  with graphic details.

I do, however, have a few issues with the game.  These are mostly minor things that don't  take away from the gameplay overall.  I'm thoroughly loving this game.

1)  Speeding tickets are 1k each, even if you'ree only going 5 miles over.  That's pretty extreme and not realistic.

2) Cops are EVERYWHERE.  I love seeing the cops around, but it gets to be a little too much when every fourth or fifth car you see is a police car.

3) I've encountered certain spots in gas stations that the truck simply cannot go over.  I found this out initially when delivering fuel.  My cab could go over the spot, but my trailer wheels would get stuck and force me to skip parking.

4) Traffic speeds!  Cars will go much faster than you all the time, even if you're going 55mph, they will fly by you.  If we have a set speed limit, the AI needs one, too.

reviewText:
Very great improvement from ETS2!

SCS Software really upped their game with this one. The buildings, scenery, vehicles, and roadside objects look even better. They went so far that they even implemented the box vans that UPS and FedEx use ito the game! The gameplay is hands down amazing. The trucks look EXTREMELY realistic and they drive like the real thing (if you're using a steering wheel). The sounds are also spot on.

One thing I really like is the implementation of police cruisers that will surprise you and sound their siren when you try the old speed-on-the-highway move from ETS2.

Long story short: ATS = ETS2 x 9000 + MERICA!

reviewText: The graphics are great, the playability is good. The map is tiny and so repetitive it severely takes away from they enjoyment. and the fines are absolutely rediculous. i was fined $1000 for 2 mph over the speed limit. in a scale area. and the cop was still on the highway. an accident? i had someone move into me (apparently the devs think i should jam on my breaks and let someone in front of me when they are right beside me and their lane is merging into mine), they fine was $900 and i lost money on the delivery because of trailer damage. Then i had someone pull out in front of me, and that one cost me $1800. this is NOT a simulator, its a game. and it should be called 'american frustration simulator'. i refuse to buy a wheel or controller for any game. if you cant play it effectively with mouse and keyboard, then dont sell it that way. i am a casual player (i have a life and a job). so when i dont play all week, i come back and actually LOSE money in  a few hours of play. i do enjoy the game, but right now, its a thumbs down until you make it enjoyable to casual players\nwith the huge issues this and its sister game ets2 has, i will not recomend this to ANYONE until it leaves the beta level and actually works the way it should. good luck if you buy it
voteText: 10 of 20 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Ok... ATS is a great game, don't get me wrong here but there is still a lot of work to be done to get this game up to standards. The number of police I see on the road is crazy, the fines they give out too are quite harsh but I do like how they put their sirens on when you go over the speed limit. There are lots of great features in this game such as the tumbleweed, which is a great touch.
The bugs... wow, don't get me started... The game often crashes on load despite all my drivers being up to date and my PC is perfectly adequate with a GTX 970 and an intel i7 4790k
Another stupidly annoying thing is how all my save games seem to dissappear... They are all clearly in my savegames folder yet don't appear on my game.
The scaling of the game is horrible. Why it takes such a short time to get places, I don't even know. ETS2 is much better scaled compared to this.
The fact that there are only two states in the game is quite frustrating but I feel that SCS may be planning to add more states as DLC content like ETS2 Going East and Scandinavia.

If you are thinking of getting this game, I recommend waiting a month or two for SCS to sort out the many bugs in the game and to add some more content to the game before buying it.
Overall I will rate this game 4/10 Mainly because of it's many bugs and issues.

reviewText:
Dismally disappointing. Literally ETS2 with a theme. Only two states, only two trucks, and incredibly short driving times, posing no actual challenge. They've spent a lot of time bigging up this game and how big and open it's going to be, and it's ended up with less content than UK Truck Sim. They've rushed it and not even used the pretense of early access.

I've also noticed that it manages to look worse than ETS2 and yet suffer from more performance problems.

Sorry SCS, refunding this one.

reviewText:
I would love to recommend this game, but I just can't. I loved playing Hard Truck 2: Kind of the Road as a kid, I love playing ETS2 now. New game by SCS set in USA, what could go wrong? Well, it did.
I mean, map and surrounding is nicely detailed, good job, but this is the only plus for the game. Roads blocked for player for no reason - those could get easily connected with different routes, but no, SCS just HAD TO make this annoying virtual barriers. Half of the cities roads are blocked, despite they are there. Map feels cramped, traveling to destination is too quick.
The game itself feels like DLC for ETS 2. Whole user interface is literally copied from ETS 2. Like seriously, is it this difficult to change layout and background of main menu along with texture of Route Advisor? It would help a lot.
And I thought this game is made by SCS, not EA. If so, why is it shipped unfinished? Only two trucks to choose from? It is riddiculous, they are not even American Classics, but some streamline modernish crap.

We were hyped for new game, yet we got just limited standalone DLC for Euro Truck. Not cool. I probably could've been happy with ATS if it was sold as DLC, but well, it didn't.

At this moment I would not buy again. And so, when my buddy asked me if should he get ATS my answer was NO. What about ETS2 then?" he asked. "Well
recommended: I hope SCS will finish game as they should before release
hoursPlayed: so they prove me wrong and ensure my money were well spent."

reviewText: Waited a long time for this one, years and was told  by the developer time after time please be patient. We don't want to release the game before it is ready. A huge hypefest about all the new features and blah blah this and it will be so worth the wait we promise. So it was FINALLY released and what did we get for our money? Two count them on two fingers yes 2 trucks and 2 trucks that have minimum modifications compared to the OLDER  game ETS2.  Now  I'm trying to notice what is really NEW and find mostly really irritating things like a cop on every corner giving me $1000.00 dollar tickets every 10 seconds.. Being ticketed for right turns on red which last time I checked was legal in America. Then started looking closer at the new details" and find some more really irritating things like concrete barriers that look like some child playing with their toys placed them willy nilly so as to create a potential hazard every 100 yrds.  Light standards with huge concrete bases so close to the lane that you would not dare travel in that lane! Hello SCS people are using keyboards to steer their trucks and you put all this crap right where someone is most likely to run into it and cause huge amounts of damage. Now lets talk about some really dumb stuff that makes me just shake my head in disbelief.  The developer paid someone to put stop signs at the intersections that already have traffic lights. No wonder it took so long to get this thing to market.  Most of the "cities" if you want to call them that are so small that they don't even have a garage or gas station. Talk about sparse. Heck most of its desert country whats so dam hard about putting up a few cactus and some brown vegetation? Now lets talk about sound quality. Let me put it this way
date: the first time I heard the "horn" on either of the 2 trucks it reminded me of the clowns car at the circus. Thats the best you can do in the three years I waited ? Can I recommend this piece of unfinished stuff?  A BIG thumbs down. I could give a rats patooty about all the new flare and other superfluous nonsense. I want my tuned trucks back
recommended: I want the dual trailers that were supposedly going to be part of ATS and some form of LAN connectivity. SCS you have lost sight of what your customers want and have chosen instead to offer a dumbed down unfinished product and sell ridiculous DLC addons such as your accessories DLC and paint job DLC's and heavy loads bs. At this rate it will take another three years just to fix what you just released instead of making any real progress."

reviewText:
As SCS Software mentioned in the description of the game, it currently only has two states, California and Nevada, with a third - Arizona - currently in development. And as of right now, only has two trucks to choose from. So the game is currently lacking content wise, only because this was built from the ground up, and there will be more content released for it in the future, some probably through free updates and others through purchases, it's up to the company for what they do. Even though it's a decent game right now, it cannot be recommened in its current state due to being incomplete content wise (trucks to choose from, states to go to, etc).

I may come back to this in the future to change my review, so stay tuned for the *update.



*I'd like to point out now that this will be way later on in the future, when there are more states and more vehicles to choose from. My best guess is that it would be at least by late 2017 at best, and early 2019 at the latest, when I believe that a sizeable amount of the game might be completed, meaning more content added to the game. I'd also like to say that I am not trying to make a major 100% guess on a timeframe for a more complete game, but for just a guess, a shot in the dark.

reviewText:
Very great improvement from ETS2!

SCS Software really upped their game with this one. The buildings, scenery, vehicles, and roadside objects look even better. They went so far that they even implemented the box vans that UPS and FedEx use ito the game! The gameplay is hands down amazing. The trucks look EXTREMELY realistic and they drive like the real thing (if you're using a steering wheel). The sounds are also spot on.

One thing I really like is the implementation of police cruisers that will surprise you and sound their siren when you try the old speed-on-the-highway move from ETS2.

Long story short: ATS = ETS2 x 9000 + MERICA!

reviewText:
I really liked Euro Truck Simulator but being American I wished there was an American version where I could drive the types of trucks I am used to seeing every day and on the right side of the road. Well, that's just what this is, and the graphics are a little better too.

Usually I don't care for simulation games at all but this one is easy to get into, has great controls that you can set up multiple ways (I use an Xbox controller with button inputs custom set up), you can easily load up your own music for your road hauls, and there are lots of neat mods to tweak the experience even more to your liking.

Its an oddly relaxing and enjoyable game with goals that keep me coming back. It takes up surprizingly little space on my HDD, and the price is quite fair for what you get unlike so many games that are early access with barely anything to even do for more money. Plus they are working on Arazona, which will be a free update.

Good stuff! Over n out.

reviewText:
After only spending a few hours in ATS, I feel like I've found a game I can just play forever and ever and never get tired of.  I was hesitant about buying it, as I know nothing of trucking, nor did I get into ETS 2 or other similar games, making this my introduction to trucking games.  I took the risk and bought it thanksto a friend, and I can't stop playing.  It is extremely fun and relaxing to just drive and/or listen to the in-game radio.  The game is beautiful!  SCS did an amazing job  with graphic details.

I do, however, have a few issues with the game.  These are mostly minor things that don't  take away from the gameplay overall.  I'm thoroughly loving this game.

1)  Speeding tickets are 1k each, even if you'ree only going 5 miles over.  That's pretty extreme and not realistic.

2) Cops are EVERYWHERE.  I love seeing the cops around, but it gets to be a little too much when every fourth or fifth car you see is a police car.

3) I've encountered certain spots in gas stations that the truck simply cannot go over.  I found this out initially when delivering fuel.  My cab could go over the spot, but my trailer wheels would get stuck and force me to skip parking.

4) Traffic speeds!  Cars will go much faster than you all the time, even if you're going 55mph, they will fly by you.  If we have a set speed limit, the AI needs one, too.

reviewText:
Real-life U.S. truck driver here.

Having put a ton of hours into ETS2, I was very excited when I learned SCS would be making another game based on trucking in my own country; not so much today. Yes, I do realize the game is very new and WIP.

Stuff I do like
Controls and plays much the same as ETS2 - hooray for XB360 gamepads!
Game is graphically beautiful!
The delivery parking options are a very much welcome addition. I've even found myself having to stop, think, and plan how I'm going to get a trailer into a tight spot.
Fines for violations are actually a real concern; even crippling!
But there's this one thing that's been wrecking it for me...

Ask just about anyone from anywhere else in the world what one of his or her major first impressions will be when visiting the United States, and I can all but guarantee one of them will be a sense of awe at how vast and wide open this land feels. That sense of openness is lost in this game.

Cities such as Los Angeles and Carlsbad, CA feel practically next door to each other, when it reality, they are over 80 miles apart through an almost entirely urbanized landscape. In game, the trips takes less time than a quick run to the corner store when the real run in a 74' truck lasts the better part of 2 hours. This feels even more pronounced when making the longest in-game trips; the sense of distance simply isn't there.

Rather surprisingly, I've recently learned the map scaling is significantly smaller than it was in ETS2. As a result, the game world feels disappointingly truncated. As others have noted, essential elements such as highway on-ramps are very short - gaining enough speed to safely merge with traffic is nigh impossible. What would normally be a challenging decent down Donner Pass, requiring careful planning and concentration, feels like it's over and gone in just a few seconds. As others have said, I feel this effectively breaks the immersion aspect of the game.

Other minor quibbles
No, you cannot drive for 14 hours. You get 11 hours in a 14 hour window
We generally don't fuel our trucks with 53' trailers at a typical gas station. There are truck stops for that...
..and speaking of truck stops, we usually don't go about nosing in" to parking spots!
I understand my critique is very harsh
date: but that's because I've done and do this for a living\n\nIn summary
recommended: I feel as though I'm "playing at" trucking with toys as a kid
hoursPlayed: rather than engaging in any sort of simulation. At this stage

votesFunny:
it simply isn't there.

Be safe out there!
-Red"

reviewText:
I can't recommend it yet. Not really because the lack of content, graphics, AI of other vehicles or because it's just standalone DLC for Euro Truck Simulator 2.

The problem is: There are three states for free, others are highly propably sold in packs via DLC. Even some new trucks might be paid in the future. I knew it when I bought it, but I can't recommend it until I see SCS won't charge ridiculous amount of money for DLCs. If they will, there are other ways how to play the DLCs without paying... Who said it? Kickass torrent? The ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥? No, I was talking about playing it via my friend's account of course!

I will change/update this review after first paid DLC is out.

NOTE: Looks like Steam now censors ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.
NOTE2: Screw you Steam!

Sitrep 01: First paid DLC is out - wheel customization. Really great DLC for game which lack content like trucks and maps. I also downloaded mod from recently added workshop which adds more traffic - this can bring FPS from 60+FPS to 15FPS and it also means often crashes on freeways and intersection, it basically show you how stupid the AI is.

Sitrep 02: Arizona is in open beta, looks nice, average scale. Still no word about new trucks. It's almost four months after the release, we only got one new truck and one new state in open beta. Before launch they said - it would be nice to have USA covered in 5 years. With this pace it'll be in 20 years.

reviewText: Maybe I'm biased as I grew up in Northern California, but I liked American Truck Simulator a lot. More, perhaps, than Euro Truck Simulator 2, which is basically the same game but set in Europe. They pretty accurately represent California and Nevada's roads, and I feel like that helps to explain why I like this better than its sister game; I can recall road trips to visit my grandmother in Bakersfield, and I used those same roads while shipping a water tank from San Rafael to Bakersfield.\n\nIt's a beautiful game, and clearly crafted with (approximate) care.

If you're like me and have gone through all the truck simulator games from the first 18WoS to this crap

reviewText:
If you like/ love Euro Truck Simulator, then I am sure you are going to enjoy this too!

Right now, at the time of writing this review there is not that much content in the game, but there is a fair amount to keep you entertained for the time being, more content will be added but most likely at a cost.

Graphics: The graphics too me seem a little upgraded compared to the original Euro Truck Sim 2, which is nice and the detailing is kinda a little better, it's the only way to explain it.  I had scaling on 400% and max graphics and was super smooth!

Audio: The audio is the same as Euro Truck sim, with some added effects coming from the world.  It is truck noises... I turned off the radio and music because I found it annoying!

Controls: This is where I got annoyed! I am using an Xbox One controller (X360 works too) but I had some problems setting it up and it took me a while because of the weird issue with the acceleration with the game!

Gameplay: The gameplay is the same as Euro Truck Simulator 2, which I did not play much off as I only played the multiplayer mod, which I am thankful to say, this version now has!
(I am unsure if ETS2 has these features but I am detailing them from ATS) - The nice fact you can hire drivers, buy trucks for them and a little more, buy a garage, upgrade it and semi customise the trucks and get your drivers to go on missions to earn you some more money is pretty awesome.  The detail in this version I find is a lot more extreme, to the point when driving around the scenery actually has things going on, there are no pedestrians on the streets, but they are in cars and wandering around a complex and outside buidings IN a small area, but there are planes flying over dusting their fields, police following people, helicopters and actual things to look at.

There is a multiplayer mod for this game already and it is pure amazing, I love everything about it.  The only problem is, there is there NO traffic at all, not even police cars on the road... The only people on the road are other players, that is it! Kinda sad!
Also is the idiots who think this game is GTA and race around, cutting on the pavement, ramming and so much more, but thankfully the Admins are very fast to actually ban them which is awesome, and there is very little of these people and players actually play the game properly mostly.  Again making this enjoyable!

The game plays more or less the same as ETS2 and is enjoyable and will be a better version when more content has arrived, so on that basis... Yes, I would recommend this game a a step up from ETS2

reviewText:
This is my opinion of the game as it stands.

After spending just a few hours in game this is what I think.
If you liked ETS2 you will like this, it is exactly the same with a few added updates (apart from truck models).

Whats the same?
Driving is the same.
Business management is the same (none existant).
Graphics are the same, (LOD levels need tweeking for longer view distance in LOD 0 (closest on ultra settings)).
Menus are the same.
Everything
Whats new?
New parking selection (skip, easy and slightly harder than easy).
Weigh bridge (annoying pull in at weigh bridge, stop and press enter to pass).
New locations to drop off at (not many new places to drop off at mind you).
Police (basically speed cameras have been taken out and put in mobile cars).
What could make the game better for me?
More business management
Own trailers (maybe drop off a trailer in your yard and get AI to complete job, just a suggestion).
Change the map scale (takes no time at all to drive 1000 miles).
Fix the AI from pulling out of junctions infront of me.
Use a better materials for assets (mode detailed and more up to date).
Police cars can detect you speeding on the other side of teh carrage way!!.
is it worth £15?
In my humble opinion YES BUT BUT more work needs doing on the engine itself to make the game more enjoyable to me I would like to see these two things.

Owning trailers.
More business management (thi is no 1).

reviewText:
Pros:
- Awesome Scenery
- Same great handling physics from ETS
- Plays nice with Keyboard, Xbox Controller or Wheel
- AI seems to be a bit better
- Playing the Classic Rock Radio while driving down a lone empty highway in Nevada? Amazing!

Cons:
- Lack of content.
- Only (2) Trucks on release as well as (2) states; even for 20 bucks that's pushing it.
- Speed limits seem odd, they change to rapidly in / out of cities. Cops are unforgiving and you'll get a fine for going   3MPH over. AI is also unrealistic in this respect, instantly changing speed from 55MPH down to 35.
- Lack of On Ramps. Has anyone from SCS every been on an American Highway? There's a leadup to gain speed! ATS just dumps you directly onto the highway with no merge zone.


Overall, a fun game. If you enjoyed Euro Truck, but wanted the American Trucks and maps, this game is for you! I've had a great time so far besides the above mentioned cons, and looking forward to what SCS and mods will bring!
