reviewText:
American Truck Simulator... Is it worth it?
Review written on 04/02/16

American Truck Simulator is basically Euro Truck Simulator 2, set in the West coast of the USA. So if you didn't like Euro Truck Simulator 2, you're probably not going to enjoy this Sim.

General jist of the game (For New Players)
So just like ETS2, you start off by creating your new, exciting delivery company and character. You then take on a few quick delivery jobs around California and Nevada (More states coming soon). Eventually, you can get loans which then allow you to purchase your own truck so you can do freight jobs where you use your own equipment. (You get more money for this)

You can then upgrade your garage to allow more spaces for employees, buy more trucks and hire employees to make more money. There is a skill tree and as you level and progress through the game, you can unlock delivery jobs such as hauling Dynamite, gassess and whatnot.

The Pros

The game is highly addictive if you're the type of person that gets satisfaction from a mundane task; it's the thought of developing your own company and working really hard to get by which is really fun. After quite a few hours on this game already, I can tell I'm quite hooked and I find that driving around isn't as boring as it looks.

The driving is just as good as ETS2, the physics are really decent and it's pretty damn realistic. But then again, I'm not a truck driver, so how would I know?

More content coming soon! This game only has 2 states so far and only two truck brands, but more is on the way, such as the Arizona state and a few more truck brands.

The Cons

This game like every other Simulator, is a massive grind and I can see myself eventually getting bored or tired of repeating myself. But you've got to remember, it is a Simulator and you're supposed to work hard for little reward.

The lack of states in this game is slightly dissapointing as you feel like there should be more places to go, however I found that after my current play time, I have seen a lot and there's still a lot to see. There are also only two car brands which is a shame as there's not much choice in what truck to buy at the start. It's 50/50 chance you'll get the same truck as me.

Speed Limits! Every country has them, but God damn! I want to scream when I'm in a 55 Mph zone when you could clearly do 70! And don't get me started on the 30 Mph limit, it's so painful!

Conclusion

If you fancy giving the game a go, why not? It's really good for the price of £14.99 and I'd reccommend at least trying it. Please remember, it is a Simulator and can be boring; if you're the type of person that just wants to get going immediately and shoot people, this isn't for you.

I am enjoying the game a lot and had to force myself to come off so I could make the badge. I'm going to go to bed, wake up, go to college, go home, and play this all evening... Again.

reviewText:
I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys an immersive experience.

While I am not a car junky, I do enjoy driving across the country with only the sound of police sirens wailing as I breeze past them at a completely reasonable 90 miles per hour.

When a fellow American decides to stop moving because there is a red light, I sometimes exercise my rights by pushing said bystander and their vehicle onto the side walk with my 10 tons of freedom.

Sometimes people decide to slow down with a semi-truck behind them and you as the driver have to decide whether or not you will teach them a lesson or deal with a concussion as your truck flips 90 degrees and slides a quarter mile down the highway.

You'll also experience crippling debt as you work literally 24 hours a day 7 days a week just to pay off the truck you purchased on money lended to you. Expect a greedy police officer around every corner to steal yet another $1,400 just for going a measly 40 mp/h above the speed limit.

I love this game. It taught me to never become a truck driver or I would end up overdrafting my bank account 3 times a day 7 days a week, as well as suffer daily concussions due to my truck flipping at least twice a day.

reviewText:
I rarely ever write a review on a game but this one definitely merits it. First off I have been looking forward to playing this since the first day I heard it was in development. Now you could call me a fanboy for ATS, but I have hundreds of hours on ETS2. First i'd like to point out the obvious facts that we all know and seem to be the griping points about the game to which I have no problem with, two trucks ( with different configurations ) and two states with 30 cities total. This was known if you read any of the dev's latest pre release blogs. Is it ETS2 quality yet?, no, but neither was ETS2 until the community embraced it and helped the dev's push it to what it has become, an absolutely AMAZING game. The same can and hopefully will be applied to ATS. Yes the initial release is a little bleak, the stock truck sounds are decent, the entire economy is modeled on the ETS platform ( which works perfectly since any of us that have played ETS are very familiar with ) Another gripe ive seen is that the graphics are sub par to ETS2. Keep in mind they went for a grittier look seeing how we're out in the desert not everything is pretty and polished its more sandblasted and rusty.
Now if you can look past the initial lack of features continue to follow me. Originally only the boxed retail version of this game was to get any DLC, which the dev's generously gave ALL of us for free including Arizona when it becomes available. Couple that with the fact that they've tripled their manpower to work on finishing the game while keeping up with updating ETS2 thats a lot of work for a smaller software company to take on. I can only look forward to seeing the amazing direction this game is going to progress in the future seeing how the modding community is already full bore churning out content on release day. Here's how I rate the game

- Same addictive game play as ETS2
- New features such as parking methods and weigh stations
- Very large map for only 30 cities
- improved AI traffic
- mesmerizing scenery transitions

I honestly have no complaints with the game other than a minor gripe about the fine amounts and the rolling radars" and a few bugs that obviously are going to be in a new game but overall I foresee myself enjoying hundreds of hours on this title as it progresses. Hands down I would highly recommend this game to a friend"

reviewText: When viewed as a stand alone game the US$19.99 for a game containing two US states (California and Nevada) and two trucks might seem steep, but there are a few factors to consider. First, SCS has already committed to Arizona and future trucks as free DLC, which is a great long term value. Second, when viewed as a function of the land area open to explore, CA and NV have about 273,000 sq mi of land area, which is about the same as Germany, Austria, Czech Republic, Switzerland, and the UK (and we didn't get all of the UK in ETS2). So while 2 states sounds small, it isn't nearly as small as is seems. Finally, because American Truck Simulator uses the same engine as ETS2 we are getting a game that has many of the bugs already ironed out.\n\nOverall, ATS is a great value. Especially when viewed as an expansion of the ETS2 world.

reviewText:
Well, I've spent far too much of my time on this game following its release.

tl;dr: Euro Truck Simulator 2 is still a better value, and likely to go on a very cheap sale sooner and more often. ATS is slightly more technically advanced and detailed, but has less content.

So why did I thumb this up?

To understand why, it might be more fair to compare this game to the ETS2: Scandinavia DLC release. It was in Scandinavia that SCS started really putting this level of love and beauty into the visual environment, and ATS seems to incorporate most or all of the under-the-hood upgrades ETS2 has gotten, as of Scandinavia. I would also tend to say Scandinavia holds less overall content. That all aside, I'll go into a list of positive and negative things about this game, as I've encountered them thus far.

Positive:

+UPDATED: The multiplayer mod is available.

+UPDATED: The trucks and trailers are both larger than in ETS2, which can introduce new challenges in driving and tight-space maneuvering.

+UPDATED: Trucks come with insurance when you purchase them, reducing the cost of repairs substantially. This element of gameplay simply wasn't present in ETS2, where you would simply pay the entirety of every repair bill on your own vehicle.

+The environment is wonderful! I'm especially pleased with the design of the urban areas, which feature places that just feel more like downtown and residential areas than anything in ETS2 or ETS2: Going East, where almost everything is an industrial district or shipping yard. San Francisco in particular was lovely.

+Trailers just feel like they have more real inertia than in ETS2. Or maybe the default braking strength is just weaker; I'm quite pleased either way.

+The new parking system is well-presented and gives real options for new, intermediate, and more advanced drivers.

+The interface and controls may not have been changed substantially from ETS2 to ATS, but that's a good thing! The ETS2 interface was clean and very well-presented; there's no need to fix what isn't broken.

+The system for hiring new drivers, giving them trucks, and letting them make money for you does not appear to have changed substantially from ETS2, except for the payouts feeling smaller. Again, this is a good thing--the system worked well in ETS2, and it works well here.

+The traffic density is quite good. It's high enough to make the roads feel alive, but not high enough to make them feel congested.

+E-Pass toll booths!

+The economy feels a bit tougher" than the economy in ETS2. What you pay for things hasn't changed

reviewText:
This is a fun game for truck fans.

I'm not familiar with American trucks, so I think there maybe some more trucks used in real life than in this game. But you can have a truck, and build your own truck empire in this game.

Truck model details are great, and you can mod your trucks. I advise newbees get some money & experience points mod to make it faster to unlock more parts and abilities, and doing this won't affect the gaming experience at all and it makes your early stage more enjoyable.

Driving physics may not be very excellent, sound neither. There are many mods to improve these, but don't expect too much for the game engine maybe a little bit outdated.

The core fun part of this game is driving truck, transporting your cargo from one place to another, and do the parking, and enjoy the beautiful scene outside.

The carbine interior is detailly made. But if player can move inside choose to sit on co-driver seat, sleep in the bed, or poop in the toilet, or do something else inside, there will be more fun.

The environment is good, but not better than that in the European Truck Simulator 2. Maybe it's because Europe is more beautiful than in America?

There is no damage model at all. You crash, you pay, and you watch yourself not getting any trouble any more. If you are grounded on the road, call emergency recovery.

I personally wish to have some heavy military trucks to drive, such as the one that can transport Abrams main battle tank.

This is a game that for relax, enjoy the driving and the landscape. Not suit for need-for-speeders.

reviewText:
Idling in the Morning

Idle questions drift through my mind sometimes (normally when I’m at work and supposed to be having more productive, less idle thoughts).
There are a few questions that always plague me when I settle at my desk in the mornings

Questions like:

“What am I doing here?”
“Why isn’t it lunchtime yet?”

and the classic

“Is there a microscopic black hole under my desk because I think time has slowed down?”
(There isn’t by the way, I’ve checked, although if it really is microscopic I might have missed it).
I recite these musings to myself like a kind of depressing mantra every morning, but it’s the afternoons when my thoughts really go off on a tangent.


Idling in the Afternoon

For example, have you ever wondered why we have two letters in the English alphabet that make the same noise, C and K?

I have....

And whilst we’re talking about C, why do we use it to make an S sound in some words?
(Circle, I’m thinking of you here)
We’ve already got a letter that can make Sssss" Sounds
recommended: why is C stepping on S’s toes?\n\nIf C did step on S’s toes
hoursPlayed: and it turned into a fight
voteText:
which one would win?
Which one would I want to win?

Don’t get me wrong
helpfulPercent: it’s not always that insightful in my mind
votesHelpful:
that was a good afternoon.


Idling my way to Relevance

Thankfully a slightly more relevant question occurred to me today
votesTotal: relevant because I was sitting at my desk subtly checking for black holes\n(I have to be subtle or my colleagues might think I’m weird).\nAnyway
votesFunny: as I was eyeballing a shady corner of one of my draws for suspicious gravitational anomalies my mind wandered towards thoughts of home (as it often does) and my plans for the evening
commentsCount:
plans which included playing American Truck Simulator.


Relevant Revelation

Now
column16: it’s no secret that I like to zone out with a good long session of European Truck Simulator 2 when time allows so I was looking forward to getting behind the wheel of a “Good Ol’ Big Rig” and trucking in a Zen-like trance across the US of A.\n\nIt was then that it occurred to me that I didn’t know which was bigger
column17: geographically speaking
column18: Europe or America.\nAs this question was obviously much more important than any actually work I was supposed to be doing
column19:
I immediately turned to my friend Google to investigate.


Factual Friction

The problem was Google didn’t seem to know the answer.

Keep in mind that whilst at work I have to be just as subtle in my clandestine internet activities as I am in my black hole survey
column20: so I could only really scan the results (whilst the boss wasn’t looking) without opening up any actual web pages.\nThis led to a list of links with snippets of information like “Europe has a slightly larger landmass” and “America is much larger than Europe
column21:
France is smaller than Texas”.

I decided that as I couldn’t investigate this properly whilst being watched by “the man” (and I was aware that whilst it seemed like a burningly important question when compared the dullness of actual “work” it wouldn’t matter to me in the slightest once I was at home and had more interesting things to do).


Fictional Facts

Anyway
column22: due to the lack of an immediately accessible answer I decided that they were probably about the same sort of size
column23: a decision which has now become fact in my mind
column24: a fact I’ve made up myself
column25: but a fact none the less.\n\nIt made sense to me
column26: If SCS had made a trucking game which spanned most of Europe then American Truck Simulator would probably be on the same sort of scale
column27: therefore America must be the same sort of size as Europe
column28:
you can’t argue with science like that.

These thoughts were still with me when I finally escaped the shackles of work and settled down in front of my PC.
Steering wheel and pedals at the ready
column29:
I fired up ATS ready for some “Stateside Trucking”


Road to Riches

For the uninitiated
column30: American Truck Simulator places you in charge of your own haulage company (as does its sister game Euro-Truck Simulator 2). You start out by choosing where you want to set up your first little base of operations and then you’re master of your own haulage destiny.\n\nUnfortunately you don’t start with any money
column31: driving skills or even a truck of your own
column32: you’re going to need to earn
column33:
learn and buy these things as you play.


Earn and Learn

The “earning and learning” elements initially come from the successful completion of “quick jobs” which you’ll find available to you from the various locales scattered across the map.
These jobs vary in length and payment; you’ll find yourself hauling all sorts of cargo across the states.

You’re working for the metaphorical “Man” with these jobs though so you won’t earn as much as you would if you were your own boss
column34: but as you haven’t got your own truck when you first start out
column35: running these contracts in the loaner rigs provided is the only way you’re going to earn a buck.\n\nWhen you’ve finished browsing the list of jobs currently available to you

column38:
or you think it might push some interesting scenery past  your windows).

A click of a button later and you’ll find yourself sitting in your borrowed rig; trailer hooked up and destination already set in the sat nav.

It’s time to get trucking!


Grand Truck Auto

Now you’re sitting behind the wheel of a big rig

not a joy ride in Grand Theft Auto.

Running red lights

Traffic transgressions aside

the dealer is going to tempt you with a wealth of optional extras from the cosmetic to the mechanical and like a kid in a sweetshop; you’re going to want them all.


Rig Responsibilities

With your chest full of pride and your wallet empty of money

drive for too long without rest and you’re going to get drowsy. Falling asleep at the wheel can really ruin your day (and your truck) so rest stops in lay-bys are a must on long drives.


Bigger

reviewText:
Introduction:American Truck Simulator is a great addition to the trucking simulator series. Although it is very common to ETS 2 in many ways it is still its own game with its own feel and vibes. The game so far has 2 states, Nevada and California. It has only 3 main truck platforms; but SCS will include more free truck and map DLCs.

Pros:Same simple settings as ETS 2
Great wheel support
Extensive graphic options
Large cities and great road layout
Amazing same physics as previous games

Cons:Very common features as in ETS 2
A few mistakes in the road signs/lights
Same company/career mode as ETS 2

Cons:If you enjoyed previous ETS games this is a good addition to your library since this is a solid, growing game. Since release this game has gained a lot of criticism since it is quite common to ETS 2. If your issue is the small map or truck selection more DLC is promised. Other than that this is game worth your buck.

reviewText:
I just barely recommended this game, and my opinion is subject to change as the game progresses; but as of now, my review is as follows.

I am an American trucker. I have been for a while now. I own my own rig. I run all 48 states, plus Canada and Alaska. I played ETS2 more than any other game in the past 30 years. (even more than super mario) I loved that game. It was the first simulation game for trucking that came anywhere near the real thing. Now, I do not live in Europe. I cannot say how similar it actually is to true Euro Trucking. Well, this is American Truck Simulator and I am an American trucker, so certain things do stick out to me. For one, no where in the USA, will you have an interstate with a state road just turning into it. You'll never find that. You will have a long on ramp and off ramp for these. Every single time. There are no splits in the interstate. Also, the layout of the truck stops is way too similar to ETS2, and nowhere near similar to true American truck stops. Yeah, I see that there are some legal issues dealing with naming the big truck stops (Loves, Petro, Pilot, Flying J, TA), but don't take something that is never a truck stop (Chevron) and turn it into one. Also, you'll never find a truck stop that just turns off of the interstate. You'll always take an exit, go a few blocks down and then it will be all by itself or surrounded by other buildings. I was really hoping that this would be more accurate. Some truckstops are challenging, while others are a cake walk. However, you will never find a truck stop that pulls off of the interstate like a rest area, and you will never find a truck stop with parallel parking. It will always be back in parking.

Now onto the trucks. I get it, the game is new. But why only 2 trucks to start out with? Maybe I'm playing it wrong, but maybe not. I'm not going to touch too much on this; but I will say I hope to see more trucks appear very soon. (Not just models, but other makes also)

My biggest beef, besides the interstate shortcomings, is the fact that the game devs decided to put this in California. (Or as some truckers call it, Commiefornia) This is the single worst state to drive a truck in. It is far from the American spirit" in regards to trucking. It has the slowest speed limit
recommended: and the most corrupt state Department of Transportation in the country. If this game were to really see the heart of American trucking
hoursPlayed: they should have started it off in the Midwest or the South. Anywhere from Kansas to Texas would have been best. Something with a high agriculture outport
voteText: high manufacturing
helpfulPercent: and even high livestock. But no
votesHelpful: we had to go with California
votesTotal: who imports most of what they ship from China. Oh well
votesFunny: I can only hope that more states will be added
commentsCount: and soon. I see that Arizona is next on the list to be released
column16: and I am just curious as to what cities they are planning on introducing
column17: and what they believe actually ships out of Arizona. Should be interesting to see.\n\nI really also wish that the backing in the game was harder. I see that it has gotten more difficult from ETS2
column18: but it is FAR from being accurate with some of the shippers and receivers around this country. How about some 90 degree blind side alley backs? Or how about some blindside parallel parks for flatbeds? These are what truckers have to deal with daily here; so why not throw a few
column19: or a ton
column20: of them into the game? It would add more of a challenge while
column23: I did give this a "yes I would recommend" vote. It is a fun simulation
column25: the simulation is fairly accurate. You won't find a better trucking simulator out there. Hell
column26: even trucking schools have worse software to teach people how to drive a truck. This is a cheap game
column28: but it has amazing potential. I hope to see this game live up to my expectations
column29: especially after having waited so long to get it.\n\nIf you are not a trucker

reviewText:
I'm going to say this outright, for those giving it a bad review and otherwise putting the game down, we all need to realize the reason the game is here in this condition is because we where pushing for it, we kept asking for it and nudging SCS for it and really put on the preasure to get this game out. I'm not going to claim its bad, its very good - But i am going to say at this point it should be labeled or treated as a early access game.

The game plays and feels very much like ETS2 - which is good, its better to have a familiar feeling game then a game that has entirely new everything and makes it so returning players have to learn everything all over again, its on a very simular engine, i believe slightly updated, so we can expect the same modding community that made ETS2 massive and awesome to do the same for ATS.

And for those saying its a EA games style thing, make a complete game, then rip everything out and sell it all back as DLC to milk more money out of it - i feel SCS isnt going to do this, they may charge for future dlc or may not, that is something only time can tell, however the prices are most likely going to be low (as they where for ETS2) and most if not all players can afford 90% of the DLC without issue. Considering the Quality of the game and the quality of the community behind it, i think we should be proud and consider ourself lucky that we get this the way we do.

Remember: We asked for this, they had gotten the game to a position they where comfortable in giving us access to it - and now all i can see if people complaining that they didnt get enough or exactly what they expected. I feel we need to cut SCS a break, and we shouldn't make them feel that they've got their foot in a pile either way they go.

reviewText:
Ever since SCS announced ATS, I was counting down the days until it was released. When they told us that it was only going to come with California, I was still going to be okay with it, I just wanted to drive my Peterbilt 389 in the U.S instead of those tiny European roads. Now that ATS has released, I can say that I am greatly impressed by it. The amount of detail that went in to the states of California and Nevada is unbelievable. Even though its running on the same engine as Euro Truck 2, it still feels like a new experience for me. It is definitley a step up from the bland cities of Euro Truck.
Things I don't like:
1. The lack of long roads. One thing I enjoyed about Euro Truck was being able to stay on one highway for a long time and just enjoy the journey on the road. On nearly every journey on ATS, there are a number of turns on to different highways, usually dont stay on one for over 5 minutes
2. Only coming with two trucks. Yes, I know there are going to be a ton of new mods that are going to make up for it, but I was looking forward to driving more high quality trucks from SCS. I am looking forward to when they do put more in the game.
3. The weigh stations. One of the biggest things I was looking forward to was learning how to do the weigh stations and what they would be like. Well, as of now, they don't do anything. The ones at the rest stops literally do not do anything, no icons or anything. They are just there. The ones on the highway will randomly ask you to pull in for a vehicle inspection. When you get there, you just stop on the icon and press enter and they will tell you to continue. You dont get to know the weight of your cargo or anything. I am hoping they will put more into them as the game continues its development.

Overall I am still very excited to be playing ATS. I know the mods will make this game what we all wanted it to be. I am now counting down the days until we can be driving across the entire U.S!

reviewText:
I'm going to say this outright, for those giving it a bad review and otherwise putting the game down, we all need to realize the reason the game is here in this condition is because we where pushing for it, we kept asking for it and nudging SCS for it and really put on the preasure to get this game out. I'm not going to claim its bad, its very good - But i am going to say at this point it should be labeled or treated as a early access game.

The game plays and feels very much like ETS2 - which is good, its better to have a familiar feeling game then a game that has entirely new everything and makes it so returning players have to learn everything all over again, its on a very simular engine, i believe slightly updated, so we can expect the same modding community that made ETS2 massive and awesome to do the same for ATS.

And for those saying its a EA games style thing, make a complete game, then rip everything out and sell it all back as DLC to milk more money out of it - i feel SCS isnt going to do this, they may charge for future dlc or may not, that is something only time can tell, however the prices are most likely going to be low (as they where for ETS2) and most if not all players can afford 90% of the DLC without issue. Considering the Quality of the game and the quality of the community behind it, i think we should be proud and consider ourself lucky that we get this the way we do.

Remember: We asked for this, they had gotten the game to a position they where comfortable in giving us access to it - and now all i can see if people complaining that they didnt get enough or exactly what they expected. I feel we need to cut SCS a break, and we shouldn't make them feel that they've got their foot in a pile either way they go.

reviewText: Wow people are making this game out to be the best game of 2016 for sim games already. Come on 10/10. This game is far from even being a 4 out of 10. A month in and the game gets worst. The put in street lights and leave stop signs so the cars stop at the green light waiting to go??? Buses still go 25 under the highway speeds. Highway signs are on the wrong side of highway still. Cars are still floating in air. They are selling it as a new game but 3 years later it is the same no differnce but US. Is it a sim or car game. Now you can turn off traffic tickets wow. Maybe they should have hired someone that understand USA driving. Cop cars was a great thing in this game and turned it into a great sim but you can now turn it off. Maybe you should have just put reduce speed signs up like we have in USA but you do not understand why we got upset with that. You are selling a game to the US market and do not understand the US market. In US we like a full game and this is far from that.\n\nIf the game was about money you got it out, missed out on millions of $ and all you had to do is waiting a few more months. I would have added some other trucks and a 4 or 5 more states at first then sold it for 28.99 and paid for you're programers to build the rest of the game.  Someone should be fired for this one. It is the most unpolished game I seen in awhile. This is like calling a plumber in to fix you toilet and he does not test and flush it to see if it works and leaves you take a crap and man that stinks, just like the game does now. You rep is on the line with people now. I bought the game because I like SCS software and ETS brand, this game is nothing new after 3 years. Pretty disappointed  in this game.

reviewText:
This is a tough one. I loved ATS, all of my hours on record I have from playing it on the first few days of release and I got 100% map in less than 20 hours and then it got boring and repetitve and I couldn't bring myself to play it anymore. Sure there are map extensions like c2c and other crap like that but that's not the quality I want from I game I payed 20 euros from, I don't want to have to rely on mods to keep this game fun for me, especially since those mods are one road that connects more cities which look pretty much the same. It was fun for first 10 hours to drive around sunny California and I have really enjoyed the content that's in there and this is where we get to why I do NOT recommend this game: It has amazing potential, it has beautiful graphics, it has fixed 99.9% of my issues with ETS2 (which we will get to in a second), the detail in it is amazing all the assets make the game look fantastic, but this game is made by a relativly small company and it doesn't have a lot of developers and all of them are working at the same time on ETS 2 and this game and maybe even coach sim, who knows? They're very, very, very slow and new content is taking bloody ages to come out and as I said previously it gets boring and unentertaining very quickly. So my advice when it comes to this game is:
1) If you have ETS 2 and all the DLC; WAIT! Just wait until this game has more contenct and get some cheap bundle where you get all the states and this game will be gold if the developers put the same effort in as they did for the base game
2) If you have ETS 2 and no DLC; You're better of buying the DLC for ETS 2 (excluding the paint DLC because that is pointless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥) and you will get far more many hours of entertainment from Scandinavia and go east then you will from this game.
And finally, if you don't have ETS nor ATS;
Get ETS2 and all the DLC as it has far more content and it will give you many more hours of enjoyment and many more hours of gameplay!
As time passes and ATS gets more content I will change this review, but untill then I can't recommend paying 20 euros for this game, not now, but as I say, this review might change!

reviewText:
I really want to leave a positive review for this game and recommend it to others.  I really do.  But after force re-starting my computer for the umpteenth time after trying to launch, I just can't.  This is my biggest gripe about the whole game.

Here are my specs:

Intel i7 - 2600K 3.4 GHz
RAM 16.0 GB
64 bit x64 windows 10 (boy do I miss windows 7 tho)
AMD Radeon HD 6900

All drivers are up do date.

The problem is this - roughly every third or fourth time I try to load a saved game, the game freezes.  I can still hear music, but I can't even ctrl-alt-del out of the game to force close it, it completely freezes my computer and forces me to do a hard reboot, which I hate.  Sometimes when I go back in the game after a re-boot it says there was an error and says reasons have to do with mods.

I have absolutely no mods on this game.  I have only the game I purchased and the updates SCS software did with the new truck.

If they ever fix this I will absolutely change my review to recommend this game, as when it works it is loads of fun.  I had never played ETS2 so I couldn't compare this to that, my gripes about in-game playing would be fines way too high and double if a cop sees you run a red light or hit someone (like it's more illegal if a cop sees you do it) but enforcement can now be turned off.

I do hate the stop lights in the middle of the interstate...and why they put spawn points for AI vehicles at a T junction to an interstate I'll never know.  The only way to actually get on the interstate from here is to pull out, slowly, in front of traffic and force them to stop.

Also the wheels of the truck while turning only turn the full degrees while stopped, not sure what that's about.

When you hire drivers and they 'couldn't find a job, $950 in fuel costs', seems odd that they don't know how to use a phone or the internet.  If SCS wants to limit funds I think it would be more realistic to have a message say, 'XXX called in sick today and could not work'.

For some reason, regardless if you are in NV or CA, you seem to be driving uphill both ways.  This could be just me.


For the pros:

Graphics are amazing.

I like the progression to higher levels, more money per level, unlocks to truck upgrades and paint jobs.

Having driven thru CA and NV, the realism for the terrain and landmarks are great, I can't wait for other states to be added.



TLDR:  I would recommend if I didn't have to force re-boot my computer every day.

reviewText: Amerecan truck simulator is better than euro truck simulator 2, mainly because of that it has cop cars, why cop cars you ask? well, at random parts of the map of euro truck simulator 2 the speed limit would say 80 so I'm going 80, speed limit changes to about 50 or something lower than 80, I see it change so I slow it down to the new speed limit but soon as it changes I get a speeding ticket. this doesn't happen everytime but when it does it tends to be at a internsection or when I'm about to go in to a tunnel. this doesn't happen on american truck simulator because if you speed near a cop car than you'll get a speeding ticket, otherwise you're fine. so this gives you more time to slow it down so you don't get a random speeding ticket. I read about speed cams in euro truck simulator 2 but haven't seen em, unless I'm just not seeing em but I'm driving a freaking 18 wheeler, I cant slow down from 80 to 30-50 speed limits in 3 seconds lol. that was so annoying in euro truck simulator 2. and yes I had the truck speed limit shown and not the car speed limit. I also noticed that the throttle control is way more sensitive, this makes it easier to mantain your speed. I cant find anything I dislike about this game.

reviewText:
I want to preface this by saying it's not just a game, it's an investment. Yes, there's only 3 trucks (with another on the way) and 2 states (with Arizona on the way), but I knew this well in advance. In fact, the game was originally just going to be California.

Like Euro Truck Simulator 2, this game is relaxing way to pass the time, see the country, and learn about it, albeit on a scaled down version. This game does a bit more than ETS 2 by recreating some locations and buildings. The cities are bigger, and some towns are so small they barely exist outside a gas station/rest area and a job site. Not every city has a garage and employment agency, so it won't be as easy to make money. Still plenty of truck customization options. Each truck has its own set of unique paintjobs too. Trailers can get longer, and on top of the longer cabs, you will have to figure out manuvering around corners. There's also multiple options for parking (and you can set it to always easy or hard in the Options). Police cars now roam the streets, so speed limits will be more enforced, and they're not as bad as they were in the beginning. Mod support has been immediate (and signs of going to Steam Workshop too).

I'm going to keep on trucking, building up my company, leveling up to upgrade my truck, and waiting for new states to unlock and trucks to buy so I can go from sea to shining sea.

reviewText:
This game isn't perfect, but it's damn near close.

The immersion of this game is quite awesome. The level of control over the settings and key bindings make it even more awesome. If you're like me and have a wheel ( I have a DFGT) it adds a different level of the game that you truly have to experience.

A few gripes I have, as everyone has already been addressing: Right turn on red. Being able to make a right turn on red is a staple of driving culture here in the United States. Everyone does it. It's safe to do, provided you actually look to see if anyone is coming, and shaves precious seconds or even minutes off of your driving time... I'd like to see that implemented a little better in the game. Also...... Speed fines. Yes, it is well known that speeding tickets are a prime source of revenue generation for law enforcement here in the US, however speeding tickets for going less than 5 over are almost non-existant, at least in my neck of the woods anyway.

To sum it all up, this game is worth every penny. It's fun. It's interesting. It's a good way to spend time. I can't wait to see more states implemented, especially the east coast. I want to see how West Virginia looks in the game.

reviewText:
So I decided that my Haulage company, Freddytrux, should start trading in the US of A. Well I must say that this English upstart, Freddytrux USA, has been finding trading conditions slightly difficult. Oh to be able to import a good old Swedish Volvo instead of the insipid Kenworth or Peterbilt trucks. Hopefully as Freddytrux USA grows then the options on the available trucks will become better.

The rozzers, or as the locals call them, the cops, seem to be incredibly mean handing out all sorts of traffic offence fines or insistant demands to be weighed. (sorry officer, I need to cut down on the pork pies.) And then there's the rather strange affair of vehicles turning right on a red light, pray tell, what is that all about? I guess it's legal though, because no rozzers have issued a demand on Freddytrux USA's limited funds for it.

The user interface will be familiar to ETS2 players, but I did get caught out on the delivery procedure a couple of times, as that is new to ATS, but that's my own fault for skipping the tutorial bit about it. I wanted to crack on and get my Kenworth rolling.

The scenery looks kind of nice despite running the game on a toaster spec laptop, and surprisingly the game tends to run smoothly with only minimal lagging. I'm guessing that some creative licence has been used in much the same way as ETS2. So far only California and Nevada are covered with Arizona coming soon, LA to The Big Apple hauls could be a while yet.

There are some improvements that could be made, more trucks to choose from and more states to drive through although my understanding is that these issues a currently being looked at. And how I would love to be able to import my cabover Volvo FH16 GlobetrotterXL from ETS2.

ATS is still recommended by me though. It's as immersive as ETS2 with new trucks to drive and new roads to explore. Must run, I have a cargo of frozen fruit needed in LA. Never fear, Freddytrux USA is here.

reviewText: I played the crap out of Euro Truck Simulator 2 and have been waiting for this game like crazy.  ATS is even more beautiful than ETS2 and it's really nice to see familiar territory!  I have a few minor quibbles here and there (severely condensed land scale, weird things like yield signs on freeway onramps (???), freeways (like the 15 and the 5) that normally have 3+ lanes in the real world only having two in-game, missing favorite freeways (was hoping that the 210 for the IE and the 78 for North County would make it in), the game shipping with only two states and only two truck brands), but I still feel that ATS is a solid enough offering for the price point they chose.  Thanks SCS!

reviewText: So after putting several hundred hours into Euro Truck Simulator 2 I was thoroughly looking forward to this game. The amount of content is minimal at best. I've played just under 2 hours and have managed to visit and explore the majority of California and yet I still have no money. Which brings me onto my next point, ALL of the fine's are too hard to compete with early game. It's like it expects you to be amazing straight off the bat. Trucks and cars seem to stop at junctions and give way for so long that the traffic backs up in both directions and you have to drive into the wrong lane and do a big loop around it all, which I get fined for as I slightly graze the car behind me backing up to make room to pull out. The spped fines seem random. Sometimes im doing 80 in a 60 zone and nothing happens but go forbid I go 38 in a 35. I'm finding it nearly imposinble to make any sort of profit and and finding the $900 odd profit from the beginning jobs very uncompelling. I'm going to recommend waiting to get this game until theres more content, more then 2 trucks (yes theres only 2 trucks in the game), and until they release a patch to fix the traffic. I saw 2 trucks stop on opposite sides of the road having a starring contest under a freeway brige for no reason which meant both sides got blocked and nobody could pull into or out of the freeway

reviewText: Well, for those who don't have a high-end computer, don't buy this game. I am using a decent machine, no frills, but no major issues. In fact, it had been glitching, so I did a fresh install of Windows 7 because I was so excited to play this game without interruption. In spite of my excitement, I can never play the game. As soon as I create a new profile and go to load the tutorial, the game crashes. no matter what. That is also not to mention that you can't change the graphics settings before the tutorial. If you can't load the tutorial on high settings, you're essentially screwed. I was terribly excited about this game, and have been following it for a long time. This game is a major letdown, and I'll never recommend it.

reviewText: I was initially enthusiastic about this title, but it is no where near as fun as Euro Truck Simulator 2. And as a result, I would recommend that title over this one. A lot of people are complaining about the lack of content, but I don't have any issues with the amount of area, only that it is utterly uninteresting terrain. Furthermore, the game is increditably punishing to new drivers. The first trucks that you drive are so underpowered that they can barely move, and when you do finally get up to speed, you are given a speeding ticket --that costs you more than you'll make from the job- if you happen to go ~2 mph over the speed limit. Then there is the AI that seems to actively try to cause traffic accidents with you --costing you yet more money. There are a few aspects of this game that I like, but ultimately it is too frustrating to spend any real time on.

reviewText: So after a few hours of playing this game i can say that I am a tad bit disappointed for a few reasons. The first of which being my initial expectations, I was expecting this game to be a throwback almost to the 18WOS: American long haul game which I killed so many hours on trucking across the US and canada, but when I log in all I see is 2 states, about 48 short of what I was expecting. On top of that the game feels like a reskinned ETS with different music, I get that its easier to make the new game like that, but I feel this game came out with about 4% of what it should have and that im going to have to pay more on DLC's to get the rest of the 96, and if thats the case, then shame on the developers. The only way I could reasonably recommend this game to anyone is if they havent played ETS yet, that way they aren't as let down as I was

reviewText:
I want to preface this by saying it's not just a game, it's an investment. Yes, there's only 3 trucks (with another on the way) and 2 states (with Arizona on the way), but I knew this well in advance. In fact, the game was originally just going to be California.

Like Euro Truck Simulator 2, this game is relaxing way to pass the time, see the country, and learn about it, albeit on a scaled down version. This game does a bit more than ETS 2 by recreating some locations and buildings. The cities are bigger, and some towns are so small they barely exist outside a gas station/rest area and a job site. Not every city has a garage and employment agency, so it won't be as easy to make money. Still plenty of truck customization options. Each truck has its own set of unique paintjobs too. Trailers can get longer, and on top of the longer cabs, you will have to figure out manuvering around corners. There's also multiple options for parking (and you can set it to always easy or hard in the Options). Police cars now roam the streets, so speed limits will be more enforced, and they're not as bad as they were in the beginning. Mod support has been immediate (and signs of going to Steam Workshop too).

I'm going to keep on trucking, building up my company, leveling up to upgrade my truck, and waiting for new states to unlock and trucks to buy so I can go from sea to shining sea.

reviewText:
I have played many of the trucking sims out on the market for many years.  Then about a year ago I bought Euro Truck Sim 2.  Very quickly found that I enjoyed the realism in the driving experience and really appreciated the Dev Group's work on improving and adding more maps and trucks to the game.  So when American Truck Simulator was announced I didn't hesitate.  SCS has not let me down at all with this newest version of their work.  Many people will complain about lack of truck choices and map size at the moment.  Please put it into perspective,  It takes time to get licenses to show the actual different makes of trucks in this game.  Most companies want their equipment painted in the best possible light so SCS has to make sure to do their best work on every truck, not just looks but function and capabilities.  As for the map some are saying that the highway driving doesn't seem long enough but please realize when the full USA is complete it will take an estimated 1 hr or more of real time to go coast to coast.  This is because of the sheer size of our country.  At this point I have zero complaints with the game and am just patiently waiting for the new updates that will come.

I do have some things I would like to see in the American version of this game but will post it to Dev's.

P.S.  I am a real life OTR Trucker so if I can enjoy it then you can too.

reviewText:
This game isn't perfect, but it's damn near close.

The immersion of this game is quite awesome. The level of control over the settings and key bindings make it even more awesome. If you're like me and have a wheel ( I have a DFGT) it adds a different level of the game that you truly have to experience.

A few gripes I have, as everyone has already been addressing: Right turn on red. Being able to make a right turn on red is a staple of driving culture here in the United States. Everyone does it. It's safe to do, provided you actually look to see if anyone is coming, and shaves precious seconds or even minutes off of your driving time... I'd like to see that implemented a little better in the game. Also...... Speed fines. Yes, it is well known that speeding tickets are a prime source of revenue generation for law enforcement here in the US, however speeding tickets for going less than 5 over are almost non-existant, at least in my neck of the woods anyway.

To sum it all up, this game is worth every penny. It's fun. It's interesting. It's a good way to spend time. I can't wait to see more states implemented, especially the east coast. I want to see how West Virginia looks in the game.

reviewText:
If you like Euro Truck Simulator, then your going to enjoy this one.  I've played the crap out of ETS2 and so far I've been enjoying this one just as much as the other.  There are pros and cons to this one, but I understand that things can be adjusted as time goes on like ETS2.
Pros-
-Trafic AI is way better.  They will stop if your in the middle of turning out into trafic.  This is very helpful when hauling those really big loads.
-The trucks sound really great.  Will be looking forward to seeing some older trucks that have great sound like my father's truck did.
-The game seems to be more alive with the foot trafic moving around the different areas.
-Almost the same UI.  This makes it easy to go from ETS2 to ATS with little to no problems learning the game.  The UI in both are easy to use.
Cons-
-The fines are a little bit much.
-No notice of speed zone changes in a lot of areas which leads to speeding fines....

reviewText: I absolutely love this Sim.  The roads are easy to drive and the trucks sound great,  lots of power,  once you can upgrade to a larger engine after you reach level 18.  I played it non stop from Tuesday at 10:00 Am when I DL'ed it to Thu with only just a few hours sleep.  I couldn't put it down.  I highly recommend ATS to anybody that likes driving Sim's.\nThat being said they did get some of the roads wrong.  The I5 between Bakersfield and LA, known as the Grapevine,\nshould have a 6% grade both north and south.  Also 58 east from Bakersfield to Tehachapi should be freeway and also has a 6% grade on it going east until you get to Tehachapi.  It's the sierra Nevada mountain range that is being traversed in both cases.  As California is not flat like some people think.  Hopefully these things will be fixed in a future update.

reviewText:
American Truck Simulator is similar to Euro Truck Simulator 2, but better, Why? ATS acts the same as ETS2, but set in America, driving full on American Trucks!

Gameplay (Pros)Now, before the hate comments come in about ATS being the same as ETS2, but set in America. I do agree but alot more, relaxing and more interesting. Now, ATS has 2 states; California and Nevada, Not alot but there is so much to explore and MUCH more detail than pervious SCS games. The cities are more bigger and detailed than ETS2, the environment is stunning and more alive. Like I remember, doing a quick job in Las Vegas I looked over to my right and, there were kids playing at skate park!

Environment (Pros)Okay, the scenary is beautiful! Driving through the Nevada desert in my owned Peterbilt, going around Cali is stunning. The amount of detail on this game is amazing. The roads look more rotten and dusty, seeing tumbleweed crossing the roads, birds or whatever they're roaming the skies. Okay, now the cities, what can I say about them? Let me say something; the cities are alot more detailed than ETS2. Like, seriously, then building look more rotten and dirty, there are alot more freedom in them. And more challenging parking areas to manouver your trailer, and with the nose at the front, you're going to hit alot of walls if you don't be careful enough!
Eddy's is by far the hardest place to park! Like, Seriously, try and park that trailer behind that wall without hitting anything!

Trucks (Pros)Okay, there are only 2 trucks in the game, in whiched they're fully licensed trucks.
There are; Peterbilt and Kenworth. Both are good looking trucks and are good starting trucks. I can't tell you much about them, but they're Worth" a try. ;)

Okay

reviewText: So after putting several hundred hours into Euro Truck Simulator 2 I was thoroughly looking forward to this game. The amount of content is minimal at best. I've played just under 2 hours and have managed to visit and explore the majority of California and yet I still have no money. Which brings me onto my next point, ALL of the fine's are too hard to compete with early game. It's like it expects you to be amazing straight off the bat. Trucks and cars seem to stop at junctions and give way for so long that the traffic backs up in both directions and you have to drive into the wrong lane and do a big loop around it all, which I get fined for as I slightly graze the car behind me backing up to make room to pull out. The spped fines seem random. Sometimes im doing 80 in a 60 zone and nothing happens but go forbid I go 38 in a 35. I'm finding it nearly imposinble to make any sort of profit and and finding the $900 odd profit from the beginning jobs very uncompelling. I'm going to recommend waiting to get this game until theres more content, more then 2 trucks (yes theres only 2 trucks in the game), and until they release a patch to fix the traffic. I saw 2 trucks stop on opposite sides of the road having a starring contest under a freeway brige for no reason which meant both sides got blocked and nobody could pull into or out of the freeway

reviewText: Well, for those who don't have a high-end computer, don't buy this game. I am using a decent machine, no frills, but no major issues. In fact, it had been glitching, so I did a fresh install of Windows 7 because I was so excited to play this game without interruption. In spite of my excitement, I can never play the game. As soon as I create a new profile and go to load the tutorial, the game crashes. no matter what. That is also not to mention that you can't change the graphics settings before the tutorial. If you can't load the tutorial on high settings, you're essentially screwed. I was terribly excited about this game, and have been following it for a long time. This game is a major letdown, and I'll never recommend it.

reviewText: I was initially enthusiastic about this title, but it is no where near as fun as Euro Truck Simulator 2. And as a result, I would recommend that title over this one. A lot of people are complaining about the lack of content, but I don't have any issues with the amount of area, only that it is utterly uninteresting terrain. Furthermore, the game is increditably punishing to new drivers. The first trucks that you drive are so underpowered that they can barely move, and when you do finally get up to speed, you are given a speeding ticket --that costs you more than you'll make from the job- if you happen to go ~2 mph over the speed limit. Then there is the AI that seems to actively try to cause traffic accidents with you --costing you yet more money. There are a few aspects of this game that I like, but ultimately it is too frustrating to spend any real time on.

reviewText:
So I decided that my Haulage company, Freddytrux, should start trading in the US of A. Well I must say that this English upstart, Freddytrux USA, has been finding trading conditions slightly difficult. Oh to be able to import a good old Swedish Volvo instead of the insipid Kenworth or Peterbilt trucks. Hopefully as Freddytrux USA grows then the options on the available trucks will become better.

The rozzers, or as the locals call them, the cops, seem to be incredibly mean handing out all sorts of traffic offence fines or insistant demands to be weighed. (sorry officer, I need to cut down on the pork pies.) And then there's the rather strange affair of vehicles turning right on a red light, pray tell, what is that all about? I guess it's legal though, because no rozzers have issued a demand on Freddytrux USA's limited funds for it.

The user interface will be familiar to ETS2 players, but I did get caught out on the delivery procedure a couple of times, as that is new to ATS, but that's my own fault for skipping the tutorial bit about it. I wanted to crack on and get my Kenworth rolling.

The scenery looks kind of nice despite running the game on a toaster spec laptop, and surprisingly the game tends to run smoothly with only minimal lagging. I'm guessing that some creative licence has been used in much the same way as ETS2. So far only California and Nevada are covered with Arizona coming soon, LA to The Big Apple hauls could be a while yet.

There are some improvements that could be made, more trucks to choose from and more states to drive through although my understanding is that these issues a currently being looked at. And how I would love to be able to import my cabover Volvo FH16 GlobetrotterXL from ETS2.

ATS is still recommended by me though. It's as immersive as ETS2 with new trucks to drive and new roads to explore. Must run, I have a cargo of frozen fruit needed in LA. Never fear, Freddytrux USA is here.

reviewText: Now, I came into this game with the same mindset as most others. I figured it would be a reskin of ETS2. Boy was I wrong, however. American Truck Simulator has a completely different feel than ETS2. The menus may be the same, but the trucks are big, brash, and tower over all of the other cars unlike in ETS2. The trailers are much longer, giving it a new challenge that I didn't face in ETS2. The map may be small, but there are many intricate details that make it fun to drive on with every delivery. I highly reccommend this game to anybody new to the driving simulator scene, or a veteran looking for a new way to experience driving.

reviewText: Amerecan truck simulator is better than euro truck simulator 2, mainly because of that it has cop cars, why cop cars you ask? well, at random parts of the map of euro truck simulator 2 the speed limit would say 80 so I'm going 80, speed limit changes to about 50 or something lower than 80, I see it change so I slow it down to the new speed limit but soon as it changes I get a speeding ticket. this doesn't happen everytime but when it does it tends to be at a internsection or when I'm about to go in to a tunnel. this doesn't happen on american truck simulator because if you speed near a cop car than you'll get a speeding ticket, otherwise you're fine. so this gives you more time to slow it down so you don't get a random speeding ticket. I read about speed cams in euro truck simulator 2 but haven't seen em, unless I'm just not seeing em but I'm driving a freaking 18 wheeler, I cant slow down from 80 to 30-50 speed limits in 3 seconds lol. that was so annoying in euro truck simulator 2. and yes I had the truck speed limit shown and not the car speed limit. I also noticed that the throttle control is way more sensitive, this makes it easier to mantain your speed. I cant find anything I dislike about this game.

reviewText:
Congratulations, you have successfully simulated the tedium of motorway driving. This 'game' is suitable only it seems, for budding Eddie Stobart drivers preparing for their first week on the job. Beyond the -repeat- tedium of overzealous police, speed limits that make me want to increase the rate time passes to actually get anywhere, and the god damn lack of any ounce of imagination when it comes to road design (seriously the most inspiring road design appears to be a series of miniature hills near Bakersfield), we see a return of invisible walls to the world of gaming, I thought had been left behind in 2006.

I bought this for two reasons, I wanted to use an controller with my computer, and I wanted a nice relaxing game. Well the controller was anything but obvious to configure, and the gameplay was less relaxing, more naeuseatingly dull.

Seriously hope this was not the efforts of more than a first year games programming student's pet project. Dont bother with the rest of the states, you appear to have run out of ideas anyway.

reviewText:
Coming from someone who played 400+ hours of Euro Truck Simulator 2, I personally feel this game is amazing. Sure, the scale is sort of small, and yes there isn't nearly as many roads as ETS2, but the cities and enviroment, and just level of detail make up for it.

Don't get me wrong, American Truck Simulator is the same game as Euro Truck Simulator 2. It's a different map, different trucks, but the game is the same. However, in saying that, I feel American Truck Simulator is funner to play personally, and I haven't touched ETS2 since.

You actually feel as if you ware driving through actual cities. The enviroments, I've driven down the same road 10 times, and still notice something new. American Trucks, in my opinion, are much funner to drive. While the map does skip some accuracy, it still feel similar. Driving through California feels like driving through California. I am a really happy camper, and plan on purchasing upcoming Map DLC to support these devs.

FOR YOU LINUX USERS:
I fully converted to Linux full time (no dual boot) in September 2015, and I must say, the Linux Version is remarkable. I have a GTX 980 and use Nvidia Proprietary Drivers (keep that in mind) and the performance is on par with the Windows Version. I even use a Logitech G27. No issues whatsoever. I'd give the SCS team a high five for this. Remarkable.

My ONLY Complaint about this game, is still the lack of Force Feedback on Logitech G27 (and other wheels) under Linux. It's purely a Game Issue, as the Linux Beta for ETS2 had Force Feeback, then it was removed and never fixed. Force Feedback works flawlessly on every other game. If they would fix this, I would be so so grateful.

reviewText: Great game, feels like ETS2 but in a fishbowl.  Graphics, much better.  Game play experience is less than ETS2 overall. Onramps at the length of a suburban home driveway.  No real long hauls, just feels smaller than ETS2, not because of only the 2 states, but just the general feel of the length of roads. reviewText:
I have played this game for a little over 35 hours as of now. Its a great game. I personally think its quite nice to be out of Europe. Ive heard many people say this is just a reskin of ETS2. That it may be, but its a darn good reskin if you ask me.
Lets get into some of the pros and cons shall we.

The Pros:
USA!
Right turn on red!
Better graphics (Scandanavia equivalent?)
Ambient enviornment sounds!
Huge trailers
etc...
(I know some of this can be achieved with mods!)

The Cons:
2 starter trucks
Small map
(This is all to be increased with updates!)

For $20, some think it may not be worth. I can see where you are coming from. If you think that its not worth the price, stick to ETS2 a little longer, wait for SCS to roll out some new states and trucks. Then see if you change your mind.'

With all of that being said, I would give this game a solid 8.5/10.

Can't wait for Arizona! :D

P.S Head on down to Oxnard in the MP... Chaos.

reviewText:
Well, folks.  Here we are.  The Hype is real and still is!

I bought ATS as it is called by players because I loved ETS2 and wanted to play an American Truck game, like the old 18 WoS days.  So far, I'm not disappointed by the game one bit.

Yeah, you only get two trucks at the start, and I'm fine with that.  The reasoning for the lack of immediate content is actually a good one for once.  It is because rather than put fake brands in the game, SCS wants to get licenses first.  But, as said by Pavel Sebor himself, getting licenses from truck manufacurers that aren't used to being approached for licenses of their product is like the chicken vs egg debate.  So, they are going about it the right way at least.

On to the gameplay.  Those of you that are familiar with ETS2 will have no problem getting used to the ATS Gameplay.  There are a lot of new things to compliment to already very good base gameplay that I hope will be making it's way to ETS2 soon as well.

Delivery Points are the biggest advancement in the gameplay system.  You can choose how difficult you want the delivery to be.  From a zero point quick drop to a 90 point drop that is so complex, even the most Veteran Driver will have a challenge are available for choosing.

Weigh Stations are new to the game.  You can be randomly chosen to go to the Scale House for Inspection.  It's an interesting feature, but a bit of a waste of time and ruins fuel economy.  Hopefully, SCS will be able to do something to give this feature more meaning.

After talking about weigh stations, we have no choice but to talk about the new police engine.  Now, the dreaded Rozzers are mobile and sneaky.  I got a Speeding Ticket for not being at 30 MPH right after the sign changed.  There needs to be a Reduced Speed Ahead sign, like in real life here in the States.

So, lets break it down to the Pros and Cons.

Pros

Familiar yet tweaked Gameplay
American Trucks
Nevada included
Scenery that will blow your mind
Easter Eggs, yes, there a few, and no, I will not tell you what they are
No curves every 20 feet like ETS2


Cons

Only two states at the beginning
Only two trucks at the beginning,  Not really a con, but may put some people off
The UI is completely Copy/Paste.  Would have loved to see the Route Adviser remodeled.  Maybe next time.
Only 64-Bit


Having looked at the facts and played a long time, I can give a solid 9 out of 10.  This game is definitely worth a buy.  It's continued development is something I look forward to.


UPDATE:  W900 is out and it's not bad.  The sounds need a little tweaking still, but at least it's there.

reviewText:
First 5 minutes of driving and my first delivery of fruit I'm stuck trying to back my trailer, so I back into the road,  and into a cop car, whose lights immediately go on and I see a $1000 fee which overdrawn my bank account.

Next delivery I'm at a green light waiting for oncoming traffic to dissipate so I can make a left turn. One genious traffic decides they don't want to go,  so I take the right-of-way and get through the light when a different traffic car behind it decides that they are tired of waiting so they plow into the side of my trailer, resulting in another $1000 fee.

Most life-like game I've ever played.

11/10 for Murphys law simulator.

I play this game with both splitters on the gearbox with clutch, on a g27 setup. I have just a minimal experience with real life big rigs, but when played from 1st person camera, it feels as if I'm actually in one of these beasts as it is very challenging,  yet somehow relaxing. I highly recommend this game for sim lovers. Yes the travel is scaled down, but it is still a great experience.

reviewText:
I have played about 28 hours at this writing, and I am enjoying immensely. For the most part I do in fact feel like I am controlling a real transport truck. I am playing with mouse and keyboard because I don't have a steering wheel, but this game makes me what to go and purchase a good wheel to play it with.

There are a few minor bugs, but they are few and far between, and they don't happen too often,

The sound track is bacically your own person music library, or you can choose from any internet radio station and the game with search for them for you. This is great as it means not listening to the same 20-30 songs over and over again.

There are little things that happen all around you, that you my not even notice, such as a train going by, or crop dusters dusting a field you are drving by, or maybe you will notice things and crash your rig trying to get a good look at the UFO's in the Nevada desert like I did.

The Nevada DLC is out at this time and was free, the Arizona  DLC is comeing soon and it will be free as well.

Although this game would be a perfect candidate for non-intrusinve advertising, such as billboards or stores and restaurants that we all know, it doesn't have anything like that.

After playing for almost 30 hours, I have to ask myself would I buy the game again...I have to answer yes.

reviewText:
I have played this game for a little over 35 hours as of now. Its a great game. I personally think its quite nice to be out of Europe. Ive heard many people say this is just a reskin of ETS2. That it may be, but its a darn good reskin if you ask me.
Lets get into some of the pros and cons shall we.

The Pros:
USA!
Right turn on red!
Better graphics (Scandanavia equivalent?)
Ambient enviornment sounds!
Huge trailers
etc...
(I know some of this can be achieved with mods!)

The Cons:
2 starter trucks
Small map
(This is all to be increased with updates!)

For $20, some think it may not be worth. I can see where you are coming from. If you think that its not worth the price, stick to ETS2 a little longer, wait for SCS to roll out some new states and trucks. Then see if you change your mind.'

With all of that being said, I would give this game a solid 8.5/10.

Can't wait for Arizona! :D

P.S Head on down to Oxnard in the MP... Chaos.

reviewText:
So, things that are unrealistic in this hyper-realistic truck-driving simulator:
*The traffic in LA, and Las Vegas is not anywhere near as bad as it is in real life. (This is a good thing)
*The intersections of freeways/highways are logical and identical and sane, and not anything like reality. (Also a good thing)
*The AI car drivers use their turn signals approx. 10x more often than actual CA drivers. (Thank you lord)
*The roads are reasonable in the towns and not anywhere near as maze like as reality. (I've been in a lot of industrial parks in California, the one's in the game are so much saner)
*Every single traffic light has a camera to catch you when you accidentally" run a red light. (Annoying
recommended: I guess)\n*A lot of the major cities are far less impressive and picturesque because of the downscaling. Admittedly

but Las Vegas was super disappointing compared to the real thing.)

Things that are super realistic and awesome:

reviewText:
As a professional truck driver with a serious mental disorder (yep, 3000 km a week in the real thing and i still get behind the wheel on the week end... :D) i realy find this game greatly enjoyable! i play it with the oculus rift dk2 and i got some minor issues like menu screens not showing in the rift, but despite that, it works flawlessly! Also, i'm really pleased with the choices for the manual transmission setup, make me want to mod my g27 shifter to add ranger and splitter buttons to it!

Only thing i would like to see added to this coolest truck sim would be some frame twisting and suspension work on acceleration. we would feel the load way better :)

For those who are complaining about any delay" about scs in delivering dlc

reviewText:
To those who are looking to buy this game take the time to read the various press releases on what the makers are planning before reading all the negative reviews and being turned away. As of right now they have released the game with the 2 states they have made. Arizona is the next on the list to be released and will be after an update and will be given free. The game is listed at a very nice $20 which is fitting.

Yes, the game engine is the same as Euro Truck Simulator 2. The difference in the games can be felt with the longer trucks and trailers along with the addition of weigh scales and the change of trailer drop off with the options. If you want to complain that there isn't enough difference between ETS2 and this game you should consider that the looks, the handling and the playability of the game is just as good. I have driven trucks over the road here in america and ETS2 was great for having fun. This game now allows people to have the same great fun in the US.

I use a G27 wheel and have it mapped out to be a great tool. The one things I wish they would change is the ability to move where the GPS A.K.A. route adisor was located. I use a triple monitor setup and it becomes difficult to look back and forth between it and the road. Outside of that the Game is a blast and completely worth the money. If you want to see what it feels like to drive a truck through america grab this game and enjoy! The motorists even cut you off like in real life.

reviewText:
For just 20 bucks I can travel across America (hopefully). Beats buying hundreds of dollars in fuel/ maintanence and thousands on plane tickets.

As a comparison, I have known SCS before they came out with Euro Truck Simulator. First Game I had from them was 18 WoS: Convoy. So lets break it down to the Pros and Cons.

Pros:
- Great Graphics - SCS has learned though constant development, As well as defining ATS as a true sim, compared to its ancestor with repetitive graphics and a pastel cabin that many users couldn't bear to drive in first person.
- True to Detail - Many of the original models from 18 WoS series has been scraped, They have literally rebuilt the game from the ground up. Most of the maps that you will see driving down though the states is much more authentic than what you see in their works 10 years ago. Although compressed, alot of major streets that are driven on have much more  resemblance to their real life counterparts.
- Research and other differences - SCS has been working hard focusing more on quality over the years, and it shows in their latest release, None of the models have been looking flat or out of place... yet.
- Challenging Parking Options- I remember that there used to be loads of space to park a trailer in older games, now everything takes up space. I used to turn my truck around 3 in game miles away from the destination, flooring it. If I was in a rush, I'd park the trailer sideways and continued off to the truck dealership. Now I'm cussing left and right trying to angle my trailer into the depot. Best challenge of the entire trip.
Cons:
- Small starting map- WoS had mutiple versions released about a year in between, and it had full maps for you to drive on. Although noted for its buggy qualities on the Prism3D engine, it was 80% enjoyable at the time. As a long time fan, I would've expected for at least a majority of the map to be completed at the time of it's debute. After experiencing a good 30 minutes of driving along the west coast, I wasn't dissipointed for its lack of content. That being said, since the title is american truck simulator and that they already have started on good ol' USA, I'm thinking that other counrties such as canada and mexico will come out as a paid DLC. Although the maps are watered down from their lengthy counperparts, I can see why driving seems to be too short for some.
- Limited Selection of Trucks- A common complaint for many fans here. With just two trucks to pick from, there isn't going to be much diversity in your fleet for now. Although this falls under the not enough content" panel
date:
owning a quality well known truck in your garage leaves a much more smug feeling than having a chinese knockoff of said truck.
- Lack of a variety of traffic lights- Specifically for turning left at some intersections.

Overall: this game is worth more than 20 bucks once its complete
recommended: but it will still be worth it compared to buying a rental car and shuttling yourself across america."

reviewText:
This game plays very similar to Euro Truck Simulator 2.  The largest downsides right now are simply lack of content (only 2 states to visit - only 2 brands of cabs to drive).  The graphics have improved since ETS2 and cities are much more detailed.  Traffic can be more dense in some areas making the driving more fun.  The ability to spot speed traps and avoid tickets is pretty cool.

This feels a bit more like DLC than a full game - but it is priced fair for what you get.  On sale this would seem like a no brainer purchase for anyone who loved ETS2.

These games are a lot more fun with a wheel but you don't need a $300 permium wheel to get into them - I've been using a cheap logitech wheel I picked up from a garage sale a number of years ago...

reviewText: It is hard to express the appeal.  Perhaps it is for the very reason that it isn't a ' kill everything that moves.  If it doesn't move, put it in your gun and kill.' I guess the closest way to describe it would be a classic transport tycoon game where you just happen to spend most of your time in the first person view of your best employee.  You can ignore the company builder component completely.  Or after you have spent some time building up your company you can devote much of your time to it.  I think players that do both will get the most from this game.\n\nYes it's only 3 states and 2 trucks, but I feel at a $20 price point this is a great deal.  SCS has a solid reputation of adding to the base game for years after release, and not just paid DLC.  If you compare the base game of ETS2 now with when it was first released it is practically an entirely new game.  This game will grow for years and they will devote their time and energy into this game rather than quickly cash in and release a half ♥♥♥♥♥ sequel.

reviewText:
Coming from someone who played 400+ hours of Euro Truck Simulator 2, I personally feel this game is amazing. Sure, the scale is sort of small, and yes there isn't nearly as many roads as ETS2, but the cities and enviroment, and just level of detail make up for it.

Don't get me wrong, American Truck Simulator is the same game as Euro Truck Simulator 2. It's a different map, different trucks, but the game is the same. However, in saying that, I feel American Truck Simulator is funner to play personally, and I haven't touched ETS2 since.

You actually feel as if you ware driving through actual cities. The enviroments, I've driven down the same road 10 times, and still notice something new. American Trucks, in my opinion, are much funner to drive. While the map does skip some accuracy, it still feel similar. Driving through California feels like driving through California. I am a really happy camper, and plan on purchasing upcoming Map DLC to support these devs.

FOR YOU LINUX USERS:
I fully converted to Linux full time (no dual boot) in September 2015, and I must say, the Linux Version is remarkable. I have a GTX 980 and use Nvidia Proprietary Drivers (keep that in mind) and the performance is on par with the Windows Version. I even use a Logitech G27. No issues whatsoever. I'd give the SCS team a high five for this. Remarkable.

My ONLY Complaint about this game, is still the lack of Force Feedback on Logitech G27 (and other wheels) under Linux. It's purely a Game Issue, as the Linux Beta for ETS2 had Force Feeback, then it was removed and never fixed. Force Feedback works flawlessly on every other game. If they would fix this, I would be so so grateful.
