reviewText:
I've never written a Steam review before, but really wanted to sing the praises of this game.

I'm someone who loves to drive in real life, and who also comes from and lives in California. I'm a fan of EuroTruck Simulator 2 (and I also lived in the UK for 5 years), but felt a lot of the scenery and layout was very repetitive and would often uninstall after only a few play sessions, although I'd reinstall it once in awhile. Solid game tho, and the business tycoon style aspect was fun.

In American Truck Simulator you really have the same game however I strongly feel they've done a fantastic job of skinning the game in such a way that really gives the feeling and spirit of the American Southwest very well. I know and have driven many times around the places in this game and while it's not 100% perfect or to scale, there's a ton of subtleties that this game gives to very much put you in something a lot like real life.

The windmills off Highway 111 (down in what is effectly the Coachella Valley, where Palm Springs is), the tree barriers found off Highway 99 that runs along the eastern side of the San Juaqin Valley (which is very different to the feel of the 5 Freeway which runs down the west side of that huge valley), the way the roads and buildings change while you drive over the Sierra Nevada pass (past Truckee) and into Nevada itself. The way the roads work around Las Vegas. All of these examples and hundreds more really give you a strong sense of what it is to drive around this part of the world, with all of the other successful elements from EuroTruck Simulator 2, including the ability to customize your music, and even just use preexisting Internet Radio streams which are all highly appropriate, to managing your own company of trucks and drivers over time.

Getting better in the game requires coming to learn what different areas of the map will throw at you to slow you down or trip you up, eg parts of a freeway being subject to harsh speed limits (and getting a huge speed fine if you miss it) or understanding that making a left onto a freeway from a country lane could take you an extra half an hour, or knowing when sharp grades are better driven around than attempted head on, all of these things are at play and create a real sense of accomplishment over time as you begin to master the routes.

This is a very fun game that's just as good as its predecessor but I think a much more realistic and engaging experience than Euro 2. The only complaint I have is some minor AI issues that can occur around some intersections and a funny thing where some intersections have both stop lights and stop signs too which seem to confuse the AI (and also isn't how America traffic works either). It's a pretty minor problem though that may even disappear someday.

Defininte recommend for anyone who liked the predecessors.

reviewText:
I've been a long term Euro Truck Simulator 2 player and when I first saw this game, I wasn't really interested. However, with all the trailers it got me hooked onto it. I purchased this game on release date and have loved it and do not regret the purchase.
Even though many people are saying it looks like ETS2, this was intended so that people will be able to play both games without having to learn completely different things, it's a great approach by SCS, something should be adopted by other game developers.
However with things coming across from ETS2, it also brings the idiotic AI where cars constantly crash into you, but as far as I'm aware, SCS have plans to work on this.
Even though there are only two states, you can't really complain considering the immense amount of detail that has gone into it, the detail blows ETS2 out of the waters.

Would thoroughly recommend to anyone.
10/10

reviewText:
Essentially a EST2 reskin. And that is not a bad thing considering EST2 has developed into one of the finest simulators available. The devs have done a good job making it feel american (many burger joints can be seen and can confirm that straight roads are in the game) however don't expect much innovation past weight stations and jets flying around the sky.

The game is still quite light content wise. Only two states (although Arizona is confirmed as a free DLC) are currently available and with 2 truck types, it can all feel a bit 'samey', however licensing issues are behind the lack of truck variety.

I recommend the game on the basis of SCS delivering a good amount of content for EST2, and can see them doing that with ATS, but just don't expect it to be different from EST2.

reviewText:
For me, this is well worth 14.99. It's just two trucks and two sates to start with, but Arizona and more trucks will be coming soon.

I have Euro Truck Sim 2, but I generally prefer Trucks and Trailers, and Scania Truck Sim, as these two old sims concentrate on the challenge of manouevering and parking rather than the driving in between. - (don't get me wrong, I still enjoy ETS2 though).

But I couldn't resist buying this - and somehow it is better than ETS2. The graphics, and atmosphere of driving along American freeways, just seems to suit the game better.

I know others have complained about the slightly smaller scale, but that might be another reason why I prefer it to ETS2. The drive is long enough to enjoy, but not too long to get boring. And with the whole of USA planned, there is still plenty of scope for long drives.

It's looking good, I just hope SCS are reasonable when they start selling the DLCs, I am prepared to pay but I will draw the line if I keep paying £15 for every 3 states. But they seem to have been good with previous releases, so I hope they will be so here.
Recommended if you like the previous trucking incarnations & want more of the same, but with the real American flavour.

reviewText:
Before I begin, I want everyone to know that I've been waiting on this game for years now. Ever since we were told they began development. I knew exactly what I was going to get, so I'm basing my review on that.

____

When you first see the game, it looks exactly like Euro Truck Simulator 2. The only differences include it being in the United States, having vehicles driven in the United States, trailers that are used in the United States, and a couple states in the United States.

After you get past the $20 price tag and actually get in the game, it's exactly as it seems. Just a reskin of ETS2. But what was to be expected? It's the same engine used to rebuild ETS2 for a different region. That's what we were told we were going to receive and that's what we got. I am not at all upset that we only get 2 states at release with Arizona coming a little later for free and 2 trucks. I knew I was getting that and I paid the price for that.

The developers wanted to go the correct route with the game and get licensing for the vehicles used so the lack of vehicles is okay. As time goes on, we'll get loads more. As far as states go, 3 might not seem like much. With the scale, it definitely seems lacking in content. But you have to remember. If they went to a more in-depth scale and added more content, then it'd take years for a single state to come out. I don't know about you, but I'd like to have 48 states before I turn 70 years old. :P

And the game is called American Truck Simulator. American. The United States is only one of dozens upon dozens of countries in America. Canada and Mexico are 2 more countries in NORTH America. Meanwhile, there's still South America that has to be scaled in. By the time we get all of that(if we ever do, the plans could change), we'd have so much map, we wouldn't be able to explore it all in a reasonable amount of time. Sure, California and Nevada might not seem like much, but they are comparable to Great Britain and France in ETS2 when you talk about size. Now add the equivelent amount of states as there are countries in ETS2 and you have the United States completed. UK and France might not seem like much on ETS2, but when you travel from one to the other, and then all the way to Poland and then up to Sweden, you start to realize that even though the map is small now, it will be much bigger later on when we have more content to play.

Not much of a regular review that you'd see on Steam, but these are my opinions on the game so far. It's a reskin of ETS2 and that's what we were told and what we paid for. No complaints here. Still a billion times better than most simulators out there.

reviewText:
If you like Euro Truck Sim 2 you'll probably enjoy this a lot. Although right now the map size is much smaller than ETS2. But for now driving across California had never felt so good. The map is decent and makes it feel akin to what driving in America would feel like. From the run down shops to the overabundant amount of self storage businesses. The sweet joy of make a trip is still there, but those long hauls aren't quite there yet since you can only travel between two states. Many of the mechanics mirror what was in ETS2, such as ranking and how the game is played. So players of ETS2 will feel right at home.

I would recommend this if you particularly liked ETS2 a lot and just want a new scenery and are willing to wait for more states and trucks. This feels barebones in a way with content as there is only two states currently and not very many trucks. Down the line, or very soon we should be getting Arizona and more trucks.

Even with the lack of content the game is still enjoyable to play and check out the new scenes.

reviewText: It is hard to express the appeal.  Perhaps it is for the very reason that it isn't a ' kill everything that moves.  If it doesn't move, put it in your gun and kill.' I guess the closest way to describe it would be a classic transport tycoon game where you just happen to spend most of your time in the first person view of your best employee.  You can ignore the company builder component completely.  Or after you have spent some time building up your company you can devote much of your time to it.  I think players that do both will get the most from this game.\n\nYes it's only 3 states and 2 trucks, but I feel at a $20 price point this is a great deal.  SCS has a solid reputation of adding to the base game for years after release, and not just paid DLC.  If you compare the base game of ETS2 now with when it was first released it is practically an entirely new game.  This game will grow for years and they will devote their time and energy into this game rather than quickly cash in and release a half ♥♥♥♥♥ sequel.

reviewText:
I have played about 28 hours at this writing, and I am enjoying immensely. For the most part I do in fact feel like I am controlling a real transport truck. I am playing with mouse and keyboard because I don't have a steering wheel, but this game makes me what to go and purchase a good wheel to play it with.

There are a few minor bugs, but they are few and far between, and they don't happen too often,

The sound track is bacically your own person music library, or you can choose from any internet radio station and the game with search for them for you. This is great as it means not listening to the same 20-30 songs over and over again.

There are little things that happen all around you, that you my not even notice, such as a train going by, or crop dusters dusting a field you are drving by, or maybe you will notice things and crash your rig trying to get a good look at the UFO's in the Nevada desert like I did.

The Nevada DLC is out at this time and was free, the Arizona  DLC is comeing soon and it will be free as well.

Although this game would be a perfect candidate for non-intrusinve advertising, such as billboards or stores and restaurants that we all know, it doesn't have anything like that.

After playing for almost 30 hours, I have to ask myself would I buy the game again...I have to answer yes.

reviewText:
US trucks are inferior to any EU truck in every aspect of performance and handling. This is not the Devs fault just the truth, EU is better than the US….

The maps are nice, if small which will be fixed with expansion packs.

Buy the game support the Devs, and pray they get the licence for more than 2 manufactures.

reviewText:
Awesome game!

I started playing ETS2 and yes it is the same gaming engine the attention to detail for the USA is outstanding!

SCS really took their  time building this game.

Yes the game could use a couple of extra states,     But for the price, it's a GREAT game and highly recomend it.

Looking forward to some DLC!
